 1235:         """
 1236:         normal(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None)
 1237: 
 1238:         Draw random samples from a normal (Gaussian) distribution.
 1239: 
 1240:         The probability density function of the normal distribution, first
 1241:         derived by De Moivre and 200 years later by both Gauss and Laplace
 1242:         independently [2]_, is often called the bell curve because of
 1243:         its characteristic shape (see the example below).
 1244: 
 1245:         The normal distributions occurs often in nature. For example, it
 1246:         describes the commonly occurring distribution of samples influenced
 1247:         by a large number of tiny, random disturbances, each with its own
 1248:         unique distribution [2]_.
 1249: 
 1250:         Parameters
 1251:         ----------
 1252:         loc : float or array_like of floats
 1253:             Mean ("center") of the distribution.
 1254:         scale : float or array_like of floats
 1255:             Standard deviation (spread or "width") of the distribution. Must be
 1256:             non-negative.
 1257:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 1258:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 1259:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 1260:             a single value is returned if ``loc`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.
 1261:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(loc, scale).size`` samples are drawn.
 1262: 
 1263:         Returns
 1264:         -------
 1265:         out : ndarray or scalar
 1266:             Drawn samples from the parameterized normal distribution.
 1267: 
 1268:         See Also
 1269:         --------
 1270:         scipy.stats.norm : probability density function, distribution or
 1271:             cumulative density function, etc.
 1272: 
 1273:         Notes
 1274:         -----
 1275:         The probability density for the Gaussian distribution is
 1276: 
 1277:         .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{ 2 \\pi \\sigma^2 }}
 1278:                          e^{ - \\frac{ (x - \\mu)^2 } {2 \\sigma^2} },
 1279: 
 1280:         where :math:`\\mu` is the mean and :math:`\\sigma` the standard
 1281:         deviation. The square of the standard deviation, :math:`\\sigma^2`,
 1282:         is called the variance.
 1283: 
 1284:         The function has its peak at the mean, and its "spread" increases with
 1285:         the standard deviation (the function reaches 0.607 times its maximum at
 1286:         :math:`x + \\sigma` and :math:`x - \\sigma` [2]_). This implies that
 1287:         `numpy.random.normal` is more likely to return samples lying close to
 1288:         the mean, rather than those far away.
 1289: 
 1290:         References
 1291:         ----------
 1292:         .. [1] Wikipedia, "Normal distribution",
 1293:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal_distribution
 1294:         .. [2] P. R. Peebles Jr., "Central Limit Theorem" in "Probability,
 1295:                Random Variables and Random Signal Principles", 4th ed., 2001,
 1296:                pp. 51, 51, 125.
 1297: 
 1298:         Examples
 1299:         --------
 1300:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 1301: 
 1302:         >>> mu, sigma = 0, 0.1 # mean and standard deviation
 1303:         >>> s = np.random.normal(mu, sigma, 1000)
 1304: 
 1305:         Verify the mean and the variance:
 1306: 
 1307:         >>> abs(mu - np.mean(s))
 1308:         0.0  # may vary
 1309: 
 1310:         >>> abs(sigma - np.std(s, ddof=1))
 1311:         0.1  # may vary
 1312: 
 1313:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 1314:         the probability density function:
 1315: 
 1316:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 1317:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 30, density=True)
 1318:         >>> plt.plot(bins, 1/(sigma * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi)) *
 1319:         ...                np.exp( - (bins - mu)**2 / (2 * sigma**2) ),
 1320:         ...          linewidth=2, color='r')
 1321:         >>> plt.show()
 1322: 
 1323:         Two-by-four array of samples from N(3, 6.25):
 1324: 
 1325:         >>> np.random.normal(3, 2.5, size=(2, 4))
 1326:         array([[-4.49401501,  4.00950034, -1.81814867,  7.29718677],   # random
 1327:                [ 0.39924804,  4.68456316,  4.99394529,  4.84057254]])  # random
 1328: 
 1329:         """
+1330:         return cont(&legacy_normal, &self._aug_state, size, self.lock, 2,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&legacy_normal), (&__pyx_v_self->_aug_state), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 2, __pyx_v_loc, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_v_scale, __pyx_n_u_scale, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NON_NEGATIVE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 1330, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 1331:                     loc, "", CONS_NONE,
 1332:                     scale, "scale", CONS_NON_NEGATIVE,
 1333:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE,
 1334:                     None)
 1335: 
+1336:     def standard_gamma(self, shape, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_47standard_gamma(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_46standard_gamma[] = "\n        standard_gamma(shape, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a standard Gamma distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a Gamma distribution with specified parameters,\n        shape (sometimes designated \"k\") and scale=1.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        shape : float or array_like of floats\n            Parameter, must be non-negative.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``shape`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(shape).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized standard gamma distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.gamma : probability density function, distribution or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density for the Gamma distribution is\n\n        .. math:: p(x) = x^{k-1}\\frac{e^{-x/\\theta}}{\\theta^k\\Gamma(k)},\n\n        where :math:`k` is the shape and :math:`\\theta` the scale,\n        and :math:`\\Gamma` is the Gamma function.\n\n        The Gamma distribution is often used to model the times to failure of\n        electronic components, and arises naturally in processes for which the\n        waiting times between Poisson distributed events are relevant.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Gamma Distribution.\" From MathWorld--A\n               Wolfram Web Resource.\n               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/GammaDistribution.html\n        .. [2] Wikipedia, \"Gamma distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> shape, sca""le = 2., 1. # mean and width\n        >>> s = np.random.standard_gamma(shape, 1000000)\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> import scipy.special as sps  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 50, density=True)\n        >>> y = bins**(shape-1) * ((np.exp(-bins/scale))/  # doctest: +SKIP\n        ...                       (sps.gamma(shape) * scale**shape))\n        >>> plt.plot(bins, y, linewidth=2, color='r')  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 1337:         """
 1338:         standard_gamma(shape, size=None)
 1339: 
 1340:         Draw samples from a standard Gamma distribution.
 1341: 
 1342:         Samples are drawn from a Gamma distribution with specified parameters,
 1343:         shape (sometimes designated "k") and scale=1.
 1344: 
 1345:         Parameters
 1346:         ----------
 1347:         shape : float or array_like of floats
 1348:             Parameter, must be non-negative.
 1349:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 1350:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 1351:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 1352:             a single value is returned if ``shape`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 1353:             ``np.array(shape).size`` samples are drawn.
 1354: 
 1355:         Returns
 1356:         -------
 1357:         out : ndarray or scalar
 1358:             Drawn samples from the parameterized standard gamma distribution.
 1359: 
 1360:         See Also
 1361:         --------
 1362:         scipy.stats.gamma : probability density function, distribution or
 1363:             cumulative density function, etc.
 1364: 
 1365:         Notes
 1366:         -----
 1367:         The probability density for the Gamma distribution is
 1368: 
 1369:         .. math:: p(x) = x^{k-1}\\frac{e^{-x/\\theta}}{\\theta^k\\Gamma(k)},
 1370: 
 1371:         where :math:`k` is the shape and :math:`\\theta` the scale,
 1372:         and :math:`\\Gamma` is the Gamma function.
 1373: 
 1374:         The Gamma distribution is often used to model the times to failure of
 1375:         electronic components, and arises naturally in processes for which the
 1376:         waiting times between Poisson distributed events are relevant.
 1377: 
 1378:         References
 1379:         ----------
 1380:         .. [1] Weisstein, Eric W. "Gamma Distribution." From MathWorld--A
 1381:                Wolfram Web Resource.
 1382:                https://mathworld.wolfram.com/GammaDistribution.html
 1383:         .. [2] Wikipedia, "Gamma distribution",
 1384:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma_distribution
 1385: 
 1386:         Examples
 1387:         --------
 1388:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 1389: 
 1390:         >>> shape, scale = 2., 1. # mean and width
 1391:         >>> s = np.random.standard_gamma(shape, 1000000)
 1392: 
 1393:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 1394:         the probability density function:
 1395: 
 1396:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 1397:         >>> import scipy.special as sps  # doctest: +SKIP
 1398:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 50, density=True)
 1399:         >>> y = bins**(shape-1) * ((np.exp(-bins/scale))/  # doctest: +SKIP
 1400:         ...                       (sps.gamma(shape) * scale**shape))
 1401:         >>> plt.plot(bins, y, linewidth=2, color='r')  # doctest: +SKIP
 1402:         >>> plt.show()
 1403: 
 1404:         """
+1405:         return cont(&legacy_standard_gamma, &self._aug_state, size, self.lock, 1,

  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);

+1411:     def gamma(self, shape, scale=1.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_49gamma(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_48gamma[] = "\n        gamma(shape, scale=1.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Gamma distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a Gamma distribution with specified parameters,\n        `shape` (sometimes designated \"k\") and `scale` (sometimes designated\n        \"theta\"), where both parameters are > 0.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        shape : float or array_like of floats\n            The shape of the gamma distribution. Must be non-negative.\n        scale : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            The scale of the gamma distribution. Must be non-negative.\n            Default is equal to 1.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``shape`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(shape, scale).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized gamma distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.gamma : probability density function, distribution or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density for the Gamma distribution is\n\n        .. math:: p(x) = x^{k-1}\\frac{e^{-x/\\theta}}{\\theta^k\\Gamma(k)},\n\n        where :math:`k` is the shape and :math:`\\theta` the scale,\n        and :math:`\\Gamma` is the Gamma function.\n\n        The Gamma distribution is often used to model the times to failure of\n        electronic components, and arises naturally in processes for which the\n        waiting times between Poisson distributed events are relevant.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Gamma Distribution.\" From MathWorld--A\n               Wolfram Web Resource.\n            ""   https://mathworld.wolfram.com/GammaDistribution.html\n        .. [2] Wikipedia, \"Gamma distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> shape, scale = 2., 2. # mean=4, std=2*sqrt(2)\n        >>> s = np.random.gamma(shape, scale, 1000)\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> import scipy.special as sps  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 50, density=True)\n        >>> y = bins**(shape-1)*(np.exp(-bins/scale) /  # doctest: +SKIP\n        ...                      (sps.gamma(shape)*scale**shape))\n        >>> plt.plot(bins, y, linewidth=2, color='r')  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 1412:         """
 1413:         gamma(shape, scale=1.0, size=None)
 1414: 
 1415:         Draw samples from a Gamma distribution.
 1416: 
 1417:         Samples are drawn from a Gamma distribution with specified parameters,
 1418:         `shape` (sometimes designated "k") and `scale` (sometimes designated
 1419:         "theta"), where both parameters are > 0.
 1420: 
 1421:         Parameters
 1422:         ----------
 1423:         shape : float or array_like of floats
 1424:             The shape of the gamma distribution. Must be non-negative.
 1425:         scale : float or array_like of floats, optional
 1426:             The scale of the gamma distribution. Must be non-negative.
 1427:             Default is equal to 1.
 1428:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 1429:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 1430:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 1431:             a single value is returned if ``shape`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.
 1432:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(shape, scale).size`` samples are drawn.
 1433: 
 1434:         Returns
 1435:         -------
 1436:         out : ndarray or scalar
 1437:             Drawn samples from the parameterized gamma distribution.
 1438: 
 1439:         See Also
 1440:         --------
 1441:         scipy.stats.gamma : probability density function, distribution or
 1442:             cumulative density function, etc.
 1443: 
 1444:         Notes
 1445:         -----
 1446:         The probability density for the Gamma distribution is
 1447: 
 1448:         .. math:: p(x) = x^{k-1}\\frac{e^{-x/\\theta}}{\\theta^k\\Gamma(k)},
 1449: 
 1450:         where :math:`k` is the shape and :math:`\\theta` the scale,
 1451:         and :math:`\\Gamma` is the Gamma function.
 1452: 
 1453:         The Gamma distribution is often used to model the times to failure of
 1454:         electronic components, and arises naturally in processes for which the
 1455:         waiting times between Poisson distributed events are relevant.
 1456: 
 1457:         References
 1458:         ----------
 1459:         .. [1] Weisstein, Eric W. "Gamma Distribution." From MathWorld--A
 1460:                Wolfram Web Resource.
 1461:                https://mathworld.wolfram.com/GammaDistribution.html
 1462:         .. [2] Wikipedia, "Gamma distribution",
 1463:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma_distribution
 1464: 
 1465:         Examples
 1466:         --------
 1467:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 1468: 
 1469:         >>> shape, scale = 2., 2. # mean=4, std=2*sqrt(2)
 1470:         >>> s = np.random.gamma(shape, scale, 1000)
 1471: 
 1472:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 1473:         the probability density function:
 1474: 
 1475:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 1476:         >>> import scipy.special as sps  # doctest: +SKIP
 1477:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 50, density=True)
 1478:         >>> y = bins**(shape-1)*(np.exp(-bins/scale) /  # doctest: +SKIP
 1479:         ...                      (sps.gamma(shape)*scale**shape))
 1480:         >>> plt.plot(bins, y, linewidth=2, color='r')  # doctest: +SKIP
 1481:         >>> plt.show()
 1482: 
 1483:         """
+1484:         return cont(&legacy_gamma, &self._aug_state, size, self.lock, 2,

+1489:     def f(self, dfnum, dfden, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_51f(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_50f[] = "\n        f(dfnum, dfden, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from an F distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from an F distribution with specified parameters,\n        `dfnum` (degrees of freedom in numerator) and `dfden` (degrees of\n        freedom in denominator), where both parameters must be greater than\n        zero.\n\n        The random variate of the F distribution (also known as the\n        Fisher distribution) is a continuous probability distribution\n        that arises in ANOVA tests, and is the ratio of two chi-square\n        variates.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        dfnum : float or array_like of floats\n            Degrees of freedom in numerator, must be > 0.\n        dfden : float or array_like of float\n            Degrees of freedom in denominator, must be > 0.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``dfnum`` and ``dfden`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(dfnum, dfden).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Fisher distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.f : probability density function, distribution or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The F statistic is used to compare in-group variances to between-group\n        variances. Calculating the distribution depends on the sampling, and\n        so it is a function of the respective degrees of freedom in the\n        problem. The variable `dfnum` is the number of samples minus one, the\n        between-groups degrees of freedom, while `dfden` is the within-groups\n        degrees of freedom, the sum of the number of samples in each group\n        minus the numbe""r of groups.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Glantz, Stanton A. \"Primer of Biostatistics.\", McGraw-Hill,\n               Fifth Edition, 2002.\n        .. [2] Wikipedia, \"F-distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        An example from Glantz[1], pp 47-40:\n\n        Two groups, children of diabetics (25 people) and children from people\n        without diabetes (25 controls). Fasting blood glucose was measured,\n        case group had a mean value of 86.1, controls had a mean value of\n        82.2. Standard deviations were 2.09 and 2.49 respectively. Are these\n        data consistent with the null hypothesis that the parents diabetic\n        status does not affect their children's blood glucose levels?\n        Calculating the F statistic from the data gives a value of 36.01.\n\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> dfnum = 1. # between group degrees of freedom\n        >>> dfden = 48. # within groups degrees of freedom\n        >>> s = np.random.f(dfnum, dfden, 1000)\n\n        The lower bound for the top 1% of the samples is :\n\n        >>> np.sort(s)[-10]\n        7.61988120985 # random\n\n        So there is about a 1% chance that the F statistic will exceed 7.62,\n        the measured value is 36, so the null hypothesis is rejected at the 1%\n        level.\n\n        ";
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_51f(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds) {
  PyObject *__pyx_v_dfnum = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_v_dfden = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_v_size = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_r = 0;
  __Pyx_RefNannyDeclarations
  __Pyx_RefNannySetupContext("f (wrapper)", 0);
  {
    static PyObject **__pyx_pyargnames[] = {&__pyx_n_s_dfnum,&__pyx_n_s_dfden,&__pyx_n_s_size,0};

    values[2] = ((PyObject *)Py_None);
    if (unlikely(__pyx_kwds)) {

        case  3: values[2] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 2);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;

        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  1: values[0] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 0);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  0: break;
        default: goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;
      }
      kw_args = PyDict_Size(__pyx_kwds);
      switch (pos_args) {
        case  0:
        if (likely((values[0] = __Pyx_PyDict_GetItemStr(__pyx_kwds, __pyx_n_s_dfnum)) != 0)) kw_args--;
        else goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  1:
        if (likely((values[1] = __Pyx_PyDict_GetItemStr(__pyx_kwds, __pyx_n_s_dfden)) != 0)) kw_args--;

          __Pyx_RaiseArgtupleInvalid("f", 0, 2, 3, 1); __PYX_ERR(0, 1489, __pyx_L3_error)

 1490:         """
 1491:         f(dfnum, dfden, size=None)
 1492: 
 1493:         Draw samples from an F distribution.
 1494: 
 1495:         Samples are drawn from an F distribution with specified parameters,
 1496:         `dfnum` (degrees of freedom in numerator) and `dfden` (degrees of
 1497:         freedom in denominator), where both parameters must be greater than
 1498:         zero.
 1499: 
 1500:         The random variate of the F distribution (also known as the
 1501:         Fisher distribution) is a continuous probability distribution
 1502:         that arises in ANOVA tests, and is the ratio of two chi-square
 1503:         variates.
 1504: 
 1505:         Parameters
 1506:         ----------
 1507:         dfnum : float or array_like of floats
 1508:             Degrees of freedom in numerator, must be > 0.
 1509:         dfden : float or array_like of float
 1510:             Degrees of freedom in denominator, must be > 0.
 1511:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 1512:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 1513:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 1514:             a single value is returned if ``dfnum`` and ``dfden`` are both scalars.
 1515:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(dfnum, dfden).size`` samples are drawn.
 1516: 
 1517:         Returns
 1518:         -------
 1519:         out : ndarray or scalar
 1520:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Fisher distribution.
 1521: 
 1522:         See Also
 1523:         --------
 1524:         scipy.stats.f : probability density function, distribution or
 1525:             cumulative density function, etc.
 1526: 
 1527:         Notes
 1528:         -----
 1529:         The F statistic is used to compare in-group variances to between-group
 1530:         variances. Calculating the distribution depends on the sampling, and
 1531:         so it is a function of the respective degrees of freedom in the
 1532:         problem. The variable `dfnum` is the number of samples minus one, the
 1533:         between-groups degrees of freedom, while `dfden` is the within-groups
 1534:         degrees of freedom, the sum of the number of samples in each group
 1535:         minus the number of groups.
 1536: 
 1537:         References
 1538:         ----------
 1539:         .. [1] Glantz, Stanton A. "Primer of Biostatistics.", McGraw-Hill,
 1540:                Fifth Edition, 2002.
 1541:         .. [2] Wikipedia, "F-distribution",
 1542:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-distribution
 1543: 
 1544:         Examples
 1545:         --------
 1546:         An example from Glantz[1], pp 47-40:
 1547: 
 1548:         Two groups, children of diabetics (25 people) and children from people
 1549:         without diabetes (25 controls). Fasting blood glucose was measured,
 1550:         case group had a mean value of 86.1, controls had a mean value of
 1551:         82.2. Standard deviations were 2.09 and 2.49 respectively. Are these
 1552:         data consistent with the null hypothesis that the parents diabetic
 1553:         status does not affect their children's blood glucose levels?
 1554:         Calculating the F statistic from the data gives a value of 36.01.
 1555: 
 1556:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 1557: 
 1558:         >>> dfnum = 1. # between group degrees of freedom
 1559:         >>> dfden = 48. # within groups degrees of freedom
 1560:         >>> s = np.random.f(dfnum, dfden, 1000)
 1561: 
 1562:         The lower bound for the top 1% of the samples is :
 1563: 
 1564:         >>> np.sort(s)[-10]
 1565:         7.61988120985 # random
 1566: 
 1567:         So there is about a 1% chance that the F statistic will exceed 7.62,
 1568:         the measured value is 36, so the null hypothesis is rejected at the 1%
 1569:         level.
 1570: 
 1571:         """
+1572:         return cont(&legacy_f, &self._aug_state, size, self.lock, 2,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&legacy_f), (&__pyx_v_self->_aug_state), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 2, __pyx_v_dfnum, __pyx_n_u_dfnum, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_POSITIVE, __pyx_v_dfden, __pyx_n_u_dfden, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_POSITIVE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 1572, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 1573:                     dfnum, "dfnum", CONS_POSITIVE,
 1574:                     dfden, "dfden", CONS_POSITIVE,
 1575:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE, None)
 1576: 
+1577:     def noncentral_f(self, dfnum, dfden, nonc, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_53noncentral_f(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_52noncentral_f[] = "\n        noncentral_f(dfnum, dfden, nonc, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from the noncentral F distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from an F distribution with specified parameters,\n        `dfnum` (degrees of freedom in numerator) and `dfden` (degrees of\n        freedom in denominator), where both parameters > 1.\n        `nonc` is the non-centrality parameter.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        dfnum : float or array_like of floats\n            Numerator degrees of freedom, must be > 0.\n\n            .. versionchanged:: 1.14.0\n               Earlier NumPy versions required dfnum > 1.\n        dfden : float or array_like of floats\n            Denominator degrees of freedom, must be > 0.\n        nonc : float or array_like of floats\n            Non-centrality parameter, the sum of the squares of the numerator\n            means, must be >= 0.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``dfnum``, ``dfden``, and ``nonc``\n            are all scalars. Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(dfnum, dfden, nonc).size``\n            samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized noncentral Fisher distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        When calculating the power of an experiment (power = probability of\n        rejecting the null hypothesis when a specific alternative is true) the\n        non-central F statistic becomes important. When the null hypothesis is\n        true, the F statistic follows a central F distribution. When the null\n        hypothesis is not true, then it follows a non-central F statistic.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Noncentral F-Distribution.\"\n               From MathWorld--A Wo""lfram Web Resource.\n               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/NoncentralF-Distribution.html\n        .. [2] Wikipedia, \"Noncentral F-distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noncentral_F-distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        In a study, testing for a specific alternative to the null hypothesis\n        requires use of the Noncentral F distribution. We need to calculate the\n        area in the tail of the distribution that exceeds the value of the F\n        distribution for the null hypothesis. We'll plot the two probability\n        distributions for comparison.\n\n        >>> dfnum = 3 # between group deg of freedom\n        >>> dfden = 20 # within groups degrees of freedom\n        >>> nonc = 3.0\n        >>> nc_vals = np.random.noncentral_f(dfnum, dfden, nonc, 1000000)\n        >>> NF = np.histogram(nc_vals, bins=50, density=True)\n        >>> c_vals = np.random.f(dfnum, dfden, 1000000)\n        >>> F = np.histogram(c_vals, bins=50, density=True)\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> plt.plot(F[1][1:], F[0])\n        >>> plt.plot(NF[1][1:], NF[0])\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 1578:         """
 1579:         noncentral_f(dfnum, dfden, nonc, size=None)
 1580: 
 1581:         Draw samples from the noncentral F distribution.
 1582: 
 1583:         Samples are drawn from an F distribution with specified parameters,
 1584:         `dfnum` (degrees of freedom in numerator) and `dfden` (degrees of
 1585:         freedom in denominator), where both parameters > 1.
 1586:         `nonc` is the non-centrality parameter.
 1587: 
 1588:         Parameters
 1589:         ----------
 1590:         dfnum : float or array_like of floats
 1591:             Numerator degrees of freedom, must be > 0.
 1592: 
 1593:             .. versionchanged:: 1.14.0
 1594:                Earlier NumPy versions required dfnum > 1.
 1595:         dfden : float or array_like of floats
 1596:             Denominator degrees of freedom, must be > 0.
 1597:         nonc : float or array_like of floats
 1598:             Non-centrality parameter, the sum of the squares of the numerator
 1599:             means, must be >= 0.
 1600:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 1601:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 1602:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 1603:             a single value is returned if ``dfnum``, ``dfden``, and ``nonc``
 1604:             are all scalars. Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(dfnum, dfden, nonc).size``
 1605:             samples are drawn.
 1606: 
 1607:         Returns
 1608:         -------
 1609:         out : ndarray or scalar
 1610:             Drawn samples from the parameterized noncentral Fisher distribution.
 1611: 
 1612:         Notes
 1613:         -----
 1614:         When calculating the power of an experiment (power = probability of
 1615:         rejecting the null hypothesis when a specific alternative is true) the
 1616:         non-central F statistic becomes important. When the null hypothesis is
 1617:         true, the F statistic follows a central F distribution. When the null
 1618:         hypothesis is not true, then it follows a non-central F statistic.
 1619: 
 1620:         References
 1621:         ----------
 1622:         .. [1] Weisstein, Eric W. "Noncentral F-Distribution."
 1623:                From MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.
 1624:                https://mathworld.wolfram.com/NoncentralF-Distribution.html
 1625:         .. [2] Wikipedia, "Noncentral F-distribution",
 1626:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noncentral_F-distribution
 1627: 
 1628:         Examples
 1629:         --------
 1630:         In a study, testing for a specific alternative to the null hypothesis
 1631:         requires use of the Noncentral F distribution. We need to calculate the
 1632:         area in the tail of the distribution that exceeds the value of the F
 1633:         distribution for the null hypothesis. We'll plot the two probability
 1634:         distributions for comparison.
 1635: 
 1636:         >>> dfnum = 3 # between group deg of freedom
 1637:         >>> dfden = 20 # within groups degrees of freedom
 1638:         >>> nonc = 3.0
 1639:         >>> nc_vals = np.random.noncentral_f(dfnum, dfden, nonc, 1000000)
 1640:         >>> NF = np.histogram(nc_vals, bins=50, density=True)
 1641:         >>> c_vals = np.random.f(dfnum, dfden, 1000000)
 1642:         >>> F = np.histogram(c_vals, bins=50, density=True)
 1643:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 1644:         >>> plt.plot(F[1][1:], F[0])
 1645:         >>> plt.plot(NF[1][1:], NF[0])
 1646:         >>> plt.show()
 1647: 
 1648:         """

+1654:     def chisquare(self, df, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_55chisquare(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_54chisquare[] = "\n        chisquare(df, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a chi-square distribution.\n\n        When `df` independent random variables, each with standard normal\n        distributions (mean 0, variance 1), are squared and summed, the\n        resulting distribution is chi-square (see Notes). This distribution\n        is often used in hypothesis testing.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        df : float or array_like of floats\n             Number of degrees of freedom, must be > 0.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``df`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(df).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized chi-square distribution.\n\n        Raises\n        ------\n        ValueError\n            When `df` <= 0 or when an inappropriate `size` (e.g. ``size=-1``)\n            is given.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The variable obtained by summing the squares of `df` independent,\n        standard normally distributed random variables:\n\n        .. math:: Q = \\sum_{i=0}^{\\mathtt{df}} X^2_i\n\n        is chi-square distributed, denoted\n\n        .. math:: Q \\sim \\chi^2_k.\n\n        The probability density function of the chi-squared distribution is\n\n        .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{(1/2)^{k/2}}{\\Gamma(k/2)}\n                         x^{k/2 - 1} e^{-x/2},\n\n        where :math:`\\Gamma` is the gamma function,\n\n        .. math:: \\Gamma(x) = \\int_0^{-\\infty} t^{x - 1} e^{-t} dt.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] NIST \"Engineering Statistics Handbook\"\n               https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda3666.htm\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        >>> np.ran""dom.chisquare(2,4)\n        array([ 1.89920014,  9.00867716,  3.13710533,  5.62318272]) # random\n\n        ";
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_55chisquare(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds) {
  PyObject *__pyx_v_df = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_v_size = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_r = 0;
  __Pyx_RefNannyDeclarations
  __Pyx_RefNannySetupContext("chisquare (wrapper)", 0);
  {

    values[1] = ((PyObject *)Py_None);
    if (unlikely(__pyx_kwds)) {
      Py_ssize_t kw_args;
      const Py_ssize_t pos_args = PyTuple_GET_SIZE(__pyx_args);
      switch (pos_args) {
        case  2: values[1] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 1);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;

        case  0: break;
        default: goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;
      }
      kw_args = PyDict_Size(__pyx_kwds);
      switch (pos_args) {
        case  0:

        else goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  1:
        if (kw_args > 0) {
          PyObject* value = __Pyx_PyDict_GetItemStr(__pyx_kwds, __pyx_n_s_size);

 1655:         """
 1656:         chisquare(df, size=None)
 1657: 
 1658:         Draw samples from a chi-square distribution.
 1659: 
 1660:         When `df` independent random variables, each with standard normal
 1661:         distributions (mean 0, variance 1), are squared and summed, the
 1662:         resulting distribution is chi-square (see Notes). This distribution
 1663:         is often used in hypothesis testing.
 1664: 
 1665:         Parameters
 1666:         ----------
 1667:         df : float or array_like of floats
 1668:              Number of degrees of freedom, must be > 0.
 1669:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 1670:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 1671:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 1672:             a single value is returned if ``df`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 1673:             ``np.array(df).size`` samples are drawn.
 1674: 
 1675:         Returns
 1676:         -------
 1677:         out : ndarray or scalar
 1678:             Drawn samples from the parameterized chi-square distribution.
 1679: 
 1680:         Raises
 1681:         ------
 1682:         ValueError
 1683:             When `df` <= 0 or when an inappropriate `size` (e.g. ``size=-1``)
 1684:             is given.
 1685: 
 1686:         Notes
 1687:         -----
 1688:         The variable obtained by summing the squares of `df` independent,
 1689:         standard normally distributed random variables:
 1690: 
 1691:         .. math:: Q = \\sum_{i=0}^{\\mathtt{df}} X^2_i
 1692: 
 1693:         is chi-square distributed, denoted
 1694: 
 1695:         .. math:: Q \\sim \\chi^2_k.
 1696: 
 1697:         The probability density function of the chi-squared distribution is
 1698: 
 1699:         .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{(1/2)^{k/2}}{\\Gamma(k/2)}
 1700:                          x^{k/2 - 1} e^{-x/2},
 1701: 
 1702:         where :math:`\\Gamma` is the gamma function,
 1703: 
 1704:         .. math:: \\Gamma(x) = \\int_0^{-\\infty} t^{x - 1} e^{-t} dt.
 1705: 
 1706:         References
 1707:         ----------
 1708:         .. [1] NIST "Engineering Statistics Handbook"
 1709:                https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda3666.htm
 1710: 
 1711:         Examples
 1712:         --------
 1713:         >>> np.random.chisquare(2,4)
 1714:         array([ 1.89920014,  9.00867716,  3.13710533,  5.62318272]) # random
 1715: 
 1716:         """
+1717:         return cont(&legacy_chisquare, &self._aug_state, size, self.lock, 1,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&legacy_chisquare), (&__pyx_v_self->_aug_state), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 1, __pyx_v_df, __pyx_n_u_df, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_POSITIVE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 1717, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 1718:                     df, "df", CONS_POSITIVE,
 1719:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE,
 1720:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE, None)
 1721: 
+1722:     def noncentral_chisquare(self, df, nonc, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_57noncentral_chisquare(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_56noncentral_chisquare[] = "\n        noncentral_chisquare(df, nonc, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a noncentral chi-square distribution.\n\n        The noncentral :math:`\\chi^2` distribution is a generalization of\n        the :math:`\\chi^2` distribution.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        df : float or array_like of floats\n            Degrees of freedom, must be > 0.\n\n            .. versionchanged:: 1.10.0\n               Earlier NumPy versions required dfnum > 1.\n        nonc : float or array_like of floats\n            Non-centrality, must be non-negative.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``df`` and ``nonc`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(df, nonc).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized noncentral chi-square distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density function for the noncentral Chi-square\n        distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(x;df,nonc) = \\sum^{\\infty}_{i=0}\n                               \\frac{e^{-nonc/2}(nonc/2)^{i}}{i!}\n                               P_{Y_{df+2i}}(x),\n\n        where :math:`Y_{q}` is the Chi-square with q degrees of freedom.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Wikipedia, \"Noncentral chi-squared distribution\"\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noncentral_chi-squared_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw values from the distribution and plot the histogram\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> values = plt.hist(np.random.noncentral_chisquare(3, 20, 100000),\n        ...                   bins=200, density=True)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        Draw values from a noncentra""l chisquare with very small noncentrality,\n        and compare to a chisquare.\n\n        >>> plt.figure()\n        >>> values = plt.hist(np.random.noncentral_chisquare(3, .0000001, 100000),\n        ...                   bins=np.arange(0., 25, .1), density=True)\n        >>> values2 = plt.hist(np.random.chisquare(3, 100000),\n        ...                    bins=np.arange(0., 25, .1), density=True)\n        >>> plt.plot(values[1][0:-1], values[0]-values2[0], 'ob')\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        Demonstrate how large values of non-centrality lead to a more symmetric\n        distribution.\n\n        >>> plt.figure()\n        >>> values = plt.hist(np.random.noncentral_chisquare(3, 20, 100000),\n        ...                   bins=200, density=True)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 1723:         """
 1724:         noncentral_chisquare(df, nonc, size=None)
 1725: 
 1726:         Draw samples from a noncentral chi-square distribution.
 1727: 
 1728:         The noncentral :math:`\\chi^2` distribution is a generalization of
 1729:         the :math:`\\chi^2` distribution.
 1730: 
 1731:         Parameters
 1732:         ----------
 1733:         df : float or array_like of floats
 1734:             Degrees of freedom, must be > 0.
 1735: 
 1736:             .. versionchanged:: 1.10.0
 1737:                Earlier NumPy versions required dfnum > 1.
 1738:         nonc : float or array_like of floats
 1739:             Non-centrality, must be non-negative.
 1740:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 1741:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 1742:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 1743:             a single value is returned if ``df`` and ``nonc`` are both scalars.
 1744:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(df, nonc).size`` samples are drawn.
 1745: 
 1746:         Returns
 1747:         -------
 1748:         out : ndarray or scalar
 1749:             Drawn samples from the parameterized noncentral chi-square distribution.
 1750: 
 1751:         Notes
 1752:         -----
 1753:         The probability density function for the noncentral Chi-square
 1754:         distribution is
 1755: 
 1756:         .. math:: P(x;df,nonc) = \\sum^{\\infty}_{i=0}
 1757:                                \\frac{e^{-nonc/2}(nonc/2)^{i}}{i!}
 1758:                                P_{Y_{df+2i}}(x),
 1759: 
 1760:         where :math:`Y_{q}` is the Chi-square with q degrees of freedom.
 1761: 
 1762:         References
 1763:         ----------
 1764:         .. [1] Wikipedia, "Noncentral chi-squared distribution"
 1765:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noncentral_chi-squared_distribution
 1766: 
 1767:         Examples
 1768:         --------
 1769:         Draw values from the distribution and plot the histogram
 1770: 
 1771:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 1772:         >>> values = plt.hist(np.random.noncentral_chisquare(3, 20, 100000),
 1773:         ...                   bins=200, density=True)
 1774:         >>> plt.show()
 1775: 
 1776:         Draw values from a noncentral chisquare with very small noncentrality,
 1777:         and compare to a chisquare.
 1778: 
 1779:         >>> plt.figure()
 1780:         >>> values = plt.hist(np.random.noncentral_chisquare(3, .0000001, 100000),
 1781:         ...                   bins=np.arange(0., 25, .1), density=True)
 1782:         >>> values2 = plt.hist(np.random.chisquare(3, 100000),
 1783:         ...                    bins=np.arange(0., 25, .1), density=True)
 1784:         >>> plt.plot(values[1][0:-1], values[0]-values2[0], 'ob')
 1785:         >>> plt.show()
 1786: 
 1787:         Demonstrate how large values of non-centrality lead to a more symmetric
 1788:         distribution.
 1789: 
 1790:         >>> plt.figure()
 1791:         >>> values = plt.hist(np.random.noncentral_chisquare(3, 20, 100000),
 1792:         ...                   bins=200, density=True)
 1793:         >>> plt.show()
 1794: 
 1795:         """

+1801:     def standard_cauchy(self, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_59standard_cauchy(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_58standard_cauchy[] = "\n        standard_cauchy(size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a standard Cauchy distribution with mode = 0.\n\n        Also known as the Lorentz distribution.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. Default is None, in which case a\n            single value is returned.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        samples : ndarray or scalar\n            The drawn samples.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density function for the full Cauchy distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(x; x_0, \\gamma) = \\frac{1}{\\pi \\gamma \\bigl[ 1+\n                  (\\frac{x-x_0}{\\gamma})^2 \\bigr] }\n\n        and the Standard Cauchy distribution just sets :math:`x_0=0` and\n        :math:`\\gamma=1`\n\n        The Cauchy distribution arises in the solution to the driven harmonic\n        oscillator problem, and also describes spectral line broadening. It\n        also describes the distribution of values at which a line tilted at\n        a random angle will cut the x axis.\n\n        When studying hypothesis tests that assume normality, seeing how the\n        tests perform on data from a Cauchy distribution is a good indicator of\n        their sensitivity to a heavy-tailed distribution, since the Cauchy looks\n        very much like a Gaussian distribution, but with heavier tails.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] NIST/SEMATECH e-Handbook of Statistical Methods, \"Cauchy\n              Distribution\",\n              https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda3663.htm\n        .. [2] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Cauchy Distribution.\" From MathWorld--A\n              Wolfram Web Resource.\n              https://mathworld.wolfram.com/CauchyDistribution.html\n        .. [3] Wikipedia, \"Cauchy distribution\"\n              https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/""Cauchy_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples and plot the distribution:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> s = np.random.standard_cauchy(1000000)\n        >>> s = s[(s>-25) & (s<25)]  # truncate distribution so it plots well\n        >>> plt.hist(s, bins=100)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_59standard_cauchy(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds) {

  PyObject *__pyx_r = 0;

    values[0] = ((PyObject *)Py_None);

      Py_ssize_t kw_args;
      const Py_ssize_t pos_args = PyTuple_GET_SIZE(__pyx_args);
      switch (pos_args) {
        case  1: values[0] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 0);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  0: break;
        default: goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;
      }
      kw_args = PyDict_Size(__pyx_kwds);
      switch (pos_args) {
        case  0:

          PyObject* value = __Pyx_PyDict_GetItemStr(__pyx_kwds, __pyx_n_s_size);

 1802:         """
 1803:         standard_cauchy(size=None)
 1804: 
 1805:         Draw samples from a standard Cauchy distribution with mode = 0.
 1806: 
 1807:         Also known as the Lorentz distribution.
 1808: 
 1809:         Parameters
 1810:         ----------
 1811:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 1812:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 1813:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. Default is None, in which case a
 1814:             single value is returned.
 1815: 
 1816:         Returns
 1817:         -------
 1818:         samples : ndarray or scalar
 1819:             The drawn samples.
 1820: 
 1821:         Notes
 1822:         -----
 1823:         The probability density function for the full Cauchy distribution is
 1824: 
 1825:         .. math:: P(x; x_0, \\gamma) = \\frac{1}{\\pi \\gamma \\bigl[ 1+
 1826:                   (\\frac{x-x_0}{\\gamma})^2 \\bigr] }
 1827: 
 1828:         and the Standard Cauchy distribution just sets :math:`x_0=0` and
 1829:         :math:`\\gamma=1`
 1830: 
 1831:         The Cauchy distribution arises in the solution to the driven harmonic
 1832:         oscillator problem, and also describes spectral line broadening. It
 1833:         also describes the distribution of values at which a line tilted at
 1834:         a random angle will cut the x axis.
 1835: 
 1836:         When studying hypothesis tests that assume normality, seeing how the
 1837:         tests perform on data from a Cauchy distribution is a good indicator of
 1838:         their sensitivity to a heavy-tailed distribution, since the Cauchy looks
 1839:         very much like a Gaussian distribution, but with heavier tails.
 1840: 
 1841:         References
 1842:         ----------
 1843:         .. [1] NIST/SEMATECH e-Handbook of Statistical Methods, "Cauchy
 1844:               Distribution",
 1845:               https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda3663.htm
 1846:         .. [2] Weisstein, Eric W. "Cauchy Distribution." From MathWorld--A
 1847:               Wolfram Web Resource.
 1848:               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/CauchyDistribution.html
 1849:         .. [3] Wikipedia, "Cauchy distribution"
 1850:               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cauchy_distribution
 1851: 
 1852:         Examples
 1853:         --------
 1854:         Draw samples and plot the distribution:
 1855: 
 1856:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 1857:         >>> s = np.random.standard_cauchy(1000000)
 1858:         >>> s = s[(s>-25) & (s<25)]  # truncate distribution so it plots well
 1859:         >>> plt.hist(s, bins=100)
 1860:         >>> plt.show()
 1861: 
 1862:         """
+1863:         return cont(&legacy_standard_cauchy, &self._aug_state, size, self.lock, 0,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&legacy_standard_cauchy), (&__pyx_v_self->_aug_state), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 0, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 1863, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 1864:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE, 0.0, "", CONS_NONE, 0.0, "", CONS_NONE, None)
 1865: 
+1866:     def standard_t(self, df, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_61standard_t(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_60standard_t[] = "\n        standard_t(df, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a standard Student's t distribution with `df` degrees\n        of freedom.\n\n        A special case of the hyperbolic distribution. As `df` gets\n        large, the result resembles that of the standard normal\n        distribution (`standard_normal`).\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        df : float or array_like of floats\n            Degrees of freedom, must be > 0.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``df`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(df).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized standard Student's t distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density function for the t distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(x, df) = \\frac{\\Gamma(\\frac{df+1}{2})}{\\sqrt{\\pi df}\n                  \\Gamma(\\frac{df}{2})}\\Bigl( 1+\\frac{x^2}{df} \\Bigr)^{-(df+1)/2}\n\n        The t test is based on an assumption that the data come from a\n        Normal distribution. The t test provides a way to test whether\n        the sample mean (that is the mean calculated from the data) is\n        a good estimate of the true mean.\n\n        The derivation of the t-distribution was first published in\n        1908 by William Gosset while working for the Guinness Brewery\n        in Dublin. Due to proprietary issues, he had to publish under\n        a pseudonym, and so he used the name Student.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Dalgaard, Peter, \"Introductory Statistics With R\",\n               Springer, 2002.\n        .. [2] Wikipedia, \"Student's t-distribution\"\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student's_t-distribution""\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        From Dalgaard page 83 [1]_, suppose the daily energy intake for 11\n        women in kilojoules (kJ) is:\n\n        >>> intake = np.array([5260., 5470, 5640, 6180, 6390, 6515, 6805, 7515, \\\n        ...                    7515, 8230, 8770])\n\n        Does their energy intake deviate systematically from the recommended\n        value of 7725 kJ?\n\n        We have 10 degrees of freedom, so is the sample mean within 95% of the\n        recommended value?\n\n        >>> s = np.random.standard_t(10, size=100000)\n        >>> np.mean(intake)\n        6753.636363636364\n        >>> intake.std(ddof=1)\n        1142.1232221373727\n\n        Calculate the t statistic, setting the ddof parameter to the unbiased\n        value so the divisor in the standard deviation will be degrees of\n        freedom, N-1.\n\n        >>> t = (np.mean(intake)-7725)/(intake.std(ddof=1)/np.sqrt(len(intake)))\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> h = plt.hist(s, bins=100, density=True)\n\n        For a one-sided t-test, how far out in the distribution does the t\n        statistic appear?\n\n        >>> np.sum(s<t) / float(len(s))\n        0.0090699999999999999  #random\n\n        So the p-value is about 0.009, which says the null hypothesis has a\n        probability of about 99% of being true.\n\n        ";

 1867:         """
 1868:         standard_t(df, size=None)
 1869: 
 1870:         Draw samples from a standard Student's t distribution with `df` degrees
 1871:         of freedom.
 1872: 
 1873:         A special case of the hyperbolic distribution. As `df` gets
 1874:         large, the result resembles that of the standard normal
 1875:         distribution (`standard_normal`).
 1876: 
 1877:         Parameters
 1878:         ----------
 1879:         df : float or array_like of floats
 1880:             Degrees of freedom, must be > 0.
 1881:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 1882:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 1883:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 1884:             a single value is returned if ``df`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 1885:             ``np.array(df).size`` samples are drawn.
 1886: 
 1887:         Returns
 1888:         -------
 1889:         out : ndarray or scalar
 1890:             Drawn samples from the parameterized standard Student's t distribution.
 1891: 
 1892:         Notes
 1893:         -----
 1894:         The probability density function for the t distribution is
 1895: 
 1896:         .. math:: P(x, df) = \\frac{\\Gamma(\\frac{df+1}{2})}{\\sqrt{\\pi df}
 1897:                   \\Gamma(\\frac{df}{2})}\\Bigl( 1+\\frac{x^2}{df} \\Bigr)^{-(df+1)/2}
 1898: 
 1899:         The t test is based on an assumption that the data come from a
 1900:         Normal distribution. The t test provides a way to test whether
 1901:         the sample mean (that is the mean calculated from the data) is
 1902:         a good estimate of the true mean.
 1903: 
 1904:         The derivation of the t-distribution was first published in
 1905:         1908 by William Gosset while working for the Guinness Brewery
 1906:         in Dublin. Due to proprietary issues, he had to publish under
 1907:         a pseudonym, and so he used the name Student.
 1908: 
 1909:         References
 1910:         ----------
 1911:         .. [1] Dalgaard, Peter, "Introductory Statistics With R",
 1912:                Springer, 2002.
 1913:         .. [2] Wikipedia, "Student's t-distribution"
 1914:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student's_t-distribution
 1915: 
 1916:         Examples
 1917:         --------
 1918:         From Dalgaard page 83 [1]_, suppose the daily energy intake for 11
 1919:         women in kilojoules (kJ) is:
 1920: 
 1921:         >>> intake = np.array([5260., 5470, 5640, 6180, 6390, 6515, 6805, 7515, \\
 1922:         ...                    7515, 8230, 8770])
 1923: 
 1924:         Does their energy intake deviate systematically from the recommended
 1925:         value of 7725 kJ?
 1926: 
 1927:         We have 10 degrees of freedom, so is the sample mean within 95% of the
 1928:         recommended value?
 1929: 
 1930:         >>> s = np.random.standard_t(10, size=100000)
 1931:         >>> np.mean(intake)
 1932:         6753.636363636364
 1933:         >>> intake.std(ddof=1)
 1934:         1142.1232221373727
 1935: 
 1936:         Calculate the t statistic, setting the ddof parameter to the unbiased
 1937:         value so the divisor in the standard deviation will be degrees of
 1938:         freedom, N-1.
 1939: 
 1940:         >>> t = (np.mean(intake)-7725)/(intake.std(ddof=1)/np.sqrt(len(intake)))
 1941:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 1942:         >>> h = plt.hist(s, bins=100, density=True)
 1943: 
 1944:         For a one-sided t-test, how far out in the distribution does the t
 1945:         statistic appear?
 1946: 
 1947:         >>> np.sum(s<t) / float(len(s))
 1948:         0.0090699999999999999  #random
 1949: 
 1950:         So the p-value is about 0.009, which says the null hypothesis has a
 1951:         probability of about 99% of being true.
 1952: 
 1953:         """
+1954:         return cont(&legacy_standard_t, &self._aug_state, size, self.lock, 1,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&legacy_standard_t), (&__pyx_v_self->_aug_state), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 1, __pyx_v_df, __pyx_n_u_df, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_POSITIVE, __pyx_int_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_int_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 1954, __pyx_L1_error)

 1956:                     0, "", CONS_NONE,
 1957:                     0, "", CONS_NONE,

 1959: 
+1960:     def vonmises(self, mu, kappa, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_63vonmises(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_62vonmises[] = "\n        vonmises(mu, kappa, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a von Mises distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a von Mises distribution with specified mode\n        (mu) and dispersion (kappa), on the interval [-pi, pi].\n\n        The von Mises distribution (also known as the circular normal\n        distribution) is a continuous probability distribution on the unit\n        circle. It may be thought of as the circular analogue of the normal\n        distribution.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        mu : float or array_like of floats\n            Mode (\"center\") of the distribution.\n        kappa : float or array_like of floats\n            Dispersion of the distribution, has to be >=0.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``mu`` and ``kappa`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(mu, kappa).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized von Mises distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.vonmises : probability density function, distribution, or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density for the von Mises distribution is\n\n        .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{e^{\\kappa cos(x-\\mu)}}{2\\pi I_0(\\kappa)},\n\n        where :math:`\\mu` is the mode and :math:`\\kappa` the dispersion,\n        and :math:`I_0(\\kappa)` is the modified Bessel function of order 0.\n\n        The von Mises is named for Richard Edler von Mises, who was born in\n        Austria-Hungary, in what is now the Ukraine. He fled to the United\n        States in 1939 and became a professor at Harvard. He worked in\n        probability theory, aerodynam""ics, fluid mechanics, and philosophy of\n        science.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Abramowitz, M. and Stegun, I. A. (Eds.). \"Handbook of\n               Mathematical Functions with Formulas, Graphs, and Mathematical\n               Tables, 9th printing,\" New York: Dover, 1972.\n        .. [2] von Mises, R., \"Mathematical Theory of Probability\n               and Statistics\", New York: Academic Press, 1964.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> mu, kappa = 0.0, 4.0 # mean and dispersion\n        >>> s = np.random.vonmises(mu, kappa, 1000)\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> from scipy.special import i0  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.hist(s, 50, density=True)\n        >>> x = np.linspace(-np.pi, np.pi, num=51)\n        >>> y = np.exp(kappa*np.cos(x-mu))/(2*np.pi*i0(kappa))  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.plot(x, y, linewidth=2, color='r')  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

      switch (pos_args) {

 1961:         """
 1962:         vonmises(mu, kappa, size=None)
 1963: 
 1964:         Draw samples from a von Mises distribution.
 1965: 
 1966:         Samples are drawn from a von Mises distribution with specified mode
 1967:         (mu) and dispersion (kappa), on the interval [-pi, pi].
 1968: 
 1969:         The von Mises distribution (also known as the circular normal
 1970:         distribution) is a continuous probability distribution on the unit
 1971:         circle. It may be thought of as the circular analogue of the normal
 1972:         distribution.
 1973: 
 1974:         Parameters
 1975:         ----------
 1976:         mu : float or array_like of floats
 1977:             Mode ("center") of the distribution.
 1978:         kappa : float or array_like of floats
 1979:             Dispersion of the distribution, has to be >=0.
 1980:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 1981:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 1982:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 1983:             a single value is returned if ``mu`` and ``kappa`` are both scalars.
 1984:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(mu, kappa).size`` samples are drawn.
 1985: 
 1986:         Returns
 1987:         -------
 1988:         out : ndarray or scalar
 1989:             Drawn samples from the parameterized von Mises distribution.
 1990: 
 1991:         See Also
 1992:         --------
 1993:         scipy.stats.vonmises : probability density function, distribution, or
 1994:             cumulative density function, etc.
 1995: 
 1996:         Notes
 1997:         -----
 1998:         The probability density for the von Mises distribution is
 1999: 
 2000:         .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{e^{\\kappa cos(x-\\mu)}}{2\\pi I_0(\\kappa)},
 2001: 
 2002:         where :math:`\\mu` is the mode and :math:`\\kappa` the dispersion,
 2003:         and :math:`I_0(\\kappa)` is the modified Bessel function of order 0.
 2004: 
 2005:         The von Mises is named for Richard Edler von Mises, who was born in
 2006:         Austria-Hungary, in what is now the Ukraine. He fled to the United
 2007:         States in 1939 and became a professor at Harvard. He worked in
 2008:         probability theory, aerodynamics, fluid mechanics, and philosophy of
 2009:         science.
 2010: 
 2011:         References
 2012:         ----------
 2013:         .. [1] Abramowitz, M. and Stegun, I. A. (Eds.). "Handbook of
 2014:                Mathematical Functions with Formulas, Graphs, and Mathematical
 2015:                Tables, 9th printing," New York: Dover, 1972.
 2016:         .. [2] von Mises, R., "Mathematical Theory of Probability
 2017:                and Statistics", New York: Academic Press, 1964.
 2018: 
 2019:         Examples
 2020:         --------
 2021:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 2022: 
 2023:         >>> mu, kappa = 0.0, 4.0 # mean and dispersion
 2024:         >>> s = np.random.vonmises(mu, kappa, 1000)
 2025: 
 2026:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 2027:         the probability density function:
 2028: 
 2029:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2030:         >>> from scipy.special import i0  # doctest: +SKIP
 2031:         >>> plt.hist(s, 50, density=True)
 2032:         >>> x = np.linspace(-np.pi, np.pi, num=51)
 2033:         >>> y = np.exp(kappa*np.cos(x-mu))/(2*np.pi*i0(kappa))  # doctest: +SKIP
 2034:         >>> plt.plot(x, y, linewidth=2, color='r')  # doctest: +SKIP
 2035:         >>> plt.show()
 2036: 
 2037:         """
+2038:         return cont(&random_vonmises, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 2,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&random_vonmises), (&__pyx_v_self->_bitgen), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 2, __pyx_v_mu, __pyx_n_u_mu, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_v_kappa, __pyx_n_u_kappa, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NON_NEGATIVE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 2038, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 2039:                     mu, "mu", CONS_NONE,
 2040:                     kappa, "kappa", CONS_NON_NEGATIVE,
 2041:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE, None)
 2042: 
+2043:     def pareto(self, a, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_65pareto(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_64pareto[] = "\n        pareto(a, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Pareto II or Lomax distribution with\n        specified shape.\n\n        The Lomax or Pareto II distribution is a shifted Pareto\n        distribution. The classical Pareto distribution can be\n        obtained from the Lomax distribution by adding 1 and\n        multiplying by the scale parameter ``m`` (see Notes). The\n        smallest value of the Lomax distribution is zero while for the\n        classical Pareto distribution it is ``mu``, where the standard\n        Pareto distribution has location ``mu = 1``. Lomax can also\n        be considered as a simplified version of the Generalized\n        Pareto distribution (available in SciPy), with the scale set\n        to one and the location set to zero.\n\n        The Pareto distribution must be greater than zero, and is\n        unbounded above. It is also known as the \"80-20 rule\". In\n        this distribution, 80 percent of the weights are in the lowest\n        20 percent of the range, while the other 20 percent fill the\n        remaining 80 percent of the range.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        a : float or array_like of floats\n            Shape of the distribution. Must be positive.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Pareto distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.lomax : probability density function, distribution or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n        scipy.stats.genpareto : probability density function, distribution or\n            cumulative density function, etc.""\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density for the Pareto distribution is\n\n        .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{am^a}{x^{a+1}}\n\n        where :math:`a` is the shape and :math:`m` the scale.\n\n        The Pareto distribution, named after the Italian economist\n        Vilfredo Pareto, is a power law probability distribution\n        useful in many real world problems. Outside the field of\n        economics it is generally referred to as the Bradford\n        distribution. Pareto developed the distribution to describe\n        the distribution of wealth in an economy. It has also found\n        use in insurance, web page access statistics, oil field sizes,\n        and many other problems, including the download frequency for\n        projects in Sourceforge [1]_. It is one of the so-called\n        \"fat-tailed\" distributions.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Francis Hunt and Paul Johnson, On the Pareto Distribution of\n               Sourceforge projects.\n        .. [2] Pareto, V. (1896). Course of Political Economy. Lausanne.\n        .. [3] Reiss, R.D., Thomas, M.(2001), Statistical Analysis of Extreme\n               Values, Birkhauser Verlag, Basel, pp 23-30.\n        .. [4] Wikipedia, \"Pareto distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pareto_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> a, m = 3., 2. # shape and mode\n        >>> s = (np.random.pareto(a, 1000) + 1) * m\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with the probability\n        density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, _ = plt.hist(s, 100, density=True)\n        >>> fit = a*m**a / bins**(a+1)\n        >>> plt.plot(bins, max(count)*fit/max(fit), linewidth=2, color='r')\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";
