 2044:         """
 2045:         pareto(a, size=None)
 2046: 
 2047:         Draw samples from a Pareto II or Lomax distribution with
 2048:         specified shape.
 2049: 
 2050:         The Lomax or Pareto II distribution is a shifted Pareto
 2051:         distribution. The classical Pareto distribution can be
 2052:         obtained from the Lomax distribution by adding 1 and
 2053:         multiplying by the scale parameter ``m`` (see Notes). The
 2054:         smallest value of the Lomax distribution is zero while for the
 2055:         classical Pareto distribution it is ``mu``, where the standard
 2056:         Pareto distribution has location ``mu = 1``. Lomax can also
 2057:         be considered as a simplified version of the Generalized
 2058:         Pareto distribution (available in SciPy), with the scale set
 2059:         to one and the location set to zero.
 2060: 
 2061:         The Pareto distribution must be greater than zero, and is
 2062:         unbounded above. It is also known as the "80-20 rule". In
 2063:         this distribution, 80 percent of the weights are in the lowest
 2064:         20 percent of the range, while the other 20 percent fill the
 2065:         remaining 80 percent of the range.
 2066: 
 2067:         Parameters
 2068:         ----------
 2069:         a : float or array_like of floats
 2070:             Shape of the distribution. Must be positive.
 2071:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2072:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2073:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2074:             a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 2075:             ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.
 2076: 
 2077:         Returns
 2078:         -------
 2079:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2080:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Pareto distribution.
 2081: 
 2082:         See Also
 2083:         --------
 2084:         scipy.stats.lomax : probability density function, distribution or
 2085:             cumulative density function, etc.
 2086:         scipy.stats.genpareto : probability density function, distribution or
 2087:             cumulative density function, etc.
 2088: 
 2089:         Notes
 2090:         -----
 2091:         The probability density for the Pareto distribution is
 2092: 
 2093:         .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{am^a}{x^{a+1}}
 2094: 
 2095:         where :math:`a` is the shape and :math:`m` the scale.
 2096: 
 2097:         The Pareto distribution, named after the Italian economist
 2098:         Vilfredo Pareto, is a power law probability distribution
 2099:         useful in many real world problems. Outside the field of
 2100:         economics it is generally referred to as the Bradford
 2101:         distribution. Pareto developed the distribution to describe
 2102:         the distribution of wealth in an economy. It has also found
 2103:         use in insurance, web page access statistics, oil field sizes,
 2104:         and many other problems, including the download frequency for
 2105:         projects in Sourceforge [1]_. It is one of the so-called
 2106:         "fat-tailed" distributions.
 2107: 
 2108:         References
 2109:         ----------
 2110:         .. [1] Francis Hunt and Paul Johnson, On the Pareto Distribution of
 2111:                Sourceforge projects.
 2112:         .. [2] Pareto, V. (1896). Course of Political Economy. Lausanne.
 2113:         .. [3] Reiss, R.D., Thomas, M.(2001), Statistical Analysis of Extreme
 2114:                Values, Birkhauser Verlag, Basel, pp 23-30.
 2115:         .. [4] Wikipedia, "Pareto distribution",
 2116:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pareto_distribution
 2117: 
 2118:         Examples
 2119:         --------
 2120:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 2121: 
 2122:         >>> a, m = 3., 2. # shape and mode
 2123:         >>> s = (np.random.pareto(a, 1000) + 1) * m
 2124: 
 2125:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with the probability
 2126:         density function:
 2127: 
 2128:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2129:         >>> count, bins, _ = plt.hist(s, 100, density=True)
 2130:         >>> fit = a*m**a / bins**(a+1)
 2131:         >>> plt.plot(bins, max(count)*fit/max(fit), linewidth=2, color='r')
 2132:         >>> plt.show()
 2133: 
 2134:         """
+2135:         return cont(&legacy_pareto, &self._aug_state, size, self.lock, 1,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&legacy_pareto), (&__pyx_v_self->_aug_state), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 1, __pyx_v_a, __pyx_n_u_a, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_POSITIVE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 2135, __pyx_L1_error)

  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;

 2136:                     a, "a", CONS_POSITIVE,
 2137:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE,

 2139: 
+2140:     def weibull(self, a, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_67weibull(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_66weibull[] = "\n        weibull(a, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Weibull distribution.\n\n        Draw samples from a 1-parameter Weibull distribution with the given\n        shape parameter `a`.\n\n        .. math:: X = (-ln(U))^{1/a}\n\n        Here, U is drawn from the uniform distribution over (0,1].\n\n        The more common 2-parameter Weibull, including a scale parameter\n        :math:`\\lambda` is just :math:`X = \\lambda(-ln(U))^{1/a}`.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        a : float or array_like of floats\n            Shape parameter of the distribution. Must be nonnegative.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Weibull distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.weibull_max\n        scipy.stats.weibull_min\n        scipy.stats.genextreme\n        gumbel\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The Weibull (or Type III asymptotic extreme value distribution\n        for smallest values, SEV Type III, or Rosin-Rammler\n        distribution) is one of a class of Generalized Extreme Value\n        (GEV) distributions used in modeling extreme value problems.\n        This class includes the Gumbel and Frechet distributions.\n\n        The probability density for the Weibull distribution is\n\n        .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{a}\n                         {\\lambda}(\\frac{x}{\\lambda})^{a-1}e^{-(x/\\lambda)^a},\n\n        where :math:`a` is the shape and :math:`\\lambda` the scale.\n\n        The function has its peak (the mode) at\n        :math:`\\lambda(\\frac{a-1}{a})^{1/a}`.\n\n        When ``a = 1``, the Weibull dis""tribution reduces to the exponential\n        distribution.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Waloddi Weibull, Royal Technical University, Stockholm,\n               1939 \"A Statistical Theory Of The Strength Of Materials\",\n               Ingeniorsvetenskapsakademiens Handlingar Nr 151, 1939,\n               Generalstabens Litografiska Anstalts Forlag, Stockholm.\n        .. [2] Waloddi Weibull, \"A Statistical Distribution Function of\n               Wide Applicability\", Journal Of Applied Mechanics ASME Paper\n               1951.\n        .. [3] Wikipedia, \"Weibull distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weibull_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> a = 5. # shape\n        >>> s = np.random.weibull(a, 1000)\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> x = np.arange(1,100.)/50.\n        >>> def weib(x,n,a):\n        ...     return (a / n) * (x / n)**(a - 1) * np.exp(-(x / n)**a)\n\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(np.random.weibull(5.,1000))\n        >>> x = np.arange(1,100.)/50.\n        >>> scale = count.max()/weib(x, 1., 5.).max()\n        >>> plt.plot(x, weib(x, 1., 5.)*scale)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 2141:         """
 2142:         weibull(a, size=None)
 2143: 
 2144:         Draw samples from a Weibull distribution.
 2145: 
 2146:         Draw samples from a 1-parameter Weibull distribution with the given
 2147:         shape parameter `a`.
 2148: 
 2149:         .. math:: X = (-ln(U))^{1/a}
 2150: 
 2151:         Here, U is drawn from the uniform distribution over (0,1].
 2152: 
 2153:         The more common 2-parameter Weibull, including a scale parameter
 2154:         :math:`\\lambda` is just :math:`X = \\lambda(-ln(U))^{1/a}`.
 2155: 
 2156:         Parameters
 2157:         ----------
 2158:         a : float or array_like of floats
 2159:             Shape parameter of the distribution. Must be nonnegative.
 2160:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2161:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2162:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2163:             a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 2164:             ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.
 2165: 
 2166:         Returns
 2167:         -------
 2168:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2169:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Weibull distribution.
 2170: 
 2171:         See Also
 2172:         --------
 2173:         scipy.stats.weibull_max
 2174:         scipy.stats.weibull_min
 2175:         scipy.stats.genextreme
 2176:         gumbel
 2177: 
 2178:         Notes
 2179:         -----
 2180:         The Weibull (or Type III asymptotic extreme value distribution
 2181:         for smallest values, SEV Type III, or Rosin-Rammler
 2182:         distribution) is one of a class of Generalized Extreme Value
 2183:         (GEV) distributions used in modeling extreme value problems.
 2184:         This class includes the Gumbel and Frechet distributions.
 2185: 
 2186:         The probability density for the Weibull distribution is
 2187: 
 2188:         .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{a}
 2189:                          {\\lambda}(\\frac{x}{\\lambda})^{a-1}e^{-(x/\\lambda)^a},
 2190: 
 2191:         where :math:`a` is the shape and :math:`\\lambda` the scale.
 2192: 
 2193:         The function has its peak (the mode) at
 2194:         :math:`\\lambda(\\frac{a-1}{a})^{1/a}`.
 2195: 
 2196:         When ``a = 1``, the Weibull distribution reduces to the exponential
 2197:         distribution.
 2198: 
 2199:         References
 2200:         ----------
 2201:         .. [1] Waloddi Weibull, Royal Technical University, Stockholm,
 2202:                1939 "A Statistical Theory Of The Strength Of Materials",
 2203:                Ingeniorsvetenskapsakademiens Handlingar Nr 151, 1939,
 2204:                Generalstabens Litografiska Anstalts Forlag, Stockholm.
 2205:         .. [2] Waloddi Weibull, "A Statistical Distribution Function of
 2206:                Wide Applicability", Journal Of Applied Mechanics ASME Paper
 2207:                1951.
 2208:         .. [3] Wikipedia, "Weibull distribution",
 2209:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weibull_distribution
 2210: 
 2211:         Examples
 2212:         --------
 2213:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 2214: 
 2215:         >>> a = 5. # shape
 2216:         >>> s = np.random.weibull(a, 1000)
 2217: 
 2218:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 2219:         the probability density function:
 2220: 
 2221:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2222:         >>> x = np.arange(1,100.)/50.
 2223:         >>> def weib(x,n,a):
 2224:         ...     return (a / n) * (x / n)**(a - 1) * np.exp(-(x / n)**a)
 2225: 
 2226:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(np.random.weibull(5.,1000))
 2227:         >>> x = np.arange(1,100.)/50.
 2228:         >>> scale = count.max()/weib(x, 1., 5.).max()
 2229:         >>> plt.plot(x, weib(x, 1., 5.)*scale)
 2230:         >>> plt.show()
 2231: 
 2232:         """
+2233:         return cont(&legacy_weibull, &self._aug_state, size, self.lock, 1,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&legacy_weibull), (&__pyx_v_self->_aug_state), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 1, __pyx_v_a, __pyx_n_u_a, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NON_NEGATIVE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 2233, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 2234:                     a, "a", CONS_NON_NEGATIVE,
 2235:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE,
 2236:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE, None)
 2237: 
+2238:     def power(self, a, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_69power(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_68power[] = "\n        power(a, size=None)\n\n        Draws samples in [0, 1] from a power distribution with positive\n        exponent a - 1.\n\n        Also known as the power function distribution.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        a : float or array_like of floats\n            Parameter of the distribution. Must be non-negative.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized power distribution.\n\n        Raises\n        ------\n        ValueError\n            If a < 1.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density function is\n\n        .. math:: P(x; a) = ax^{a-1}, 0 \\le x \\le 1, a>0.\n\n        The power function distribution is just the inverse of the Pareto\n        distribution. It may also be seen as a special case of the Beta\n        distribution.\n\n        It is used, for example, in modeling the over-reporting of insurance\n        claims.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Christian Kleiber, Samuel Kotz, \"Statistical size distributions\n               in economics and actuarial sciences\", Wiley, 2003.\n        .. [2] Heckert, N. A. and Filliben, James J. \"NIST Handbook 148:\n               Dataplot Reference Manual, Volume 2: Let Subcommands and Library\n               Functions\", National Institute of Standards and Technology\n               Handbook Series, June 2003.\n               https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/software/dataplot/refman2/auxillar/powpdf.pdf\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> a = 5. # shape\n        >>> samples = 1000\n      ""  >>> s = np.random.power(a, samples)\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, bins=30)\n        >>> x = np.linspace(0, 1, 100)\n        >>> y = a*x**(a-1.)\n        >>> normed_y = samples*np.diff(bins)[0]*y\n        >>> plt.plot(x, normed_y)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        Compare the power function distribution to the inverse of the Pareto.\n\n        >>> from scipy import stats # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> rvs = np.random.power(5, 1000000)\n        >>> rvsp = np.random.pareto(5, 1000000)\n        >>> xx = np.linspace(0,1,100)\n        >>> powpdf = stats.powerlaw.pdf(xx,5)  # doctest: +SKIP\n\n        >>> plt.figure()\n        >>> plt.hist(rvs, bins=50, density=True)\n        >>> plt.plot(xx,powpdf,'r-')  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.title('np.random.power(5)')\n\n        >>> plt.figure()\n        >>> plt.hist(1./(1.+rvsp), bins=50, density=True)\n        >>> plt.plot(xx,powpdf,'r-')  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.title('inverse of 1 + np.random.pareto(5)')\n\n        >>> plt.figure()\n        >>> plt.hist(1./(1.+rvsp), bins=50, density=True)\n        >>> plt.plot(xx,powpdf,'r-')  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.title('inverse of stats.pareto(5)')\n\n        ";

 2239:         """
 2240:         power(a, size=None)
 2241: 
 2242:         Draws samples in [0, 1] from a power distribution with positive
 2243:         exponent a - 1.
 2244: 
 2245:         Also known as the power function distribution.
 2246: 
 2247:         Parameters
 2248:         ----------
 2249:         a : float or array_like of floats
 2250:             Parameter of the distribution. Must be non-negative.
 2251:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2252:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2253:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2254:             a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 2255:             ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.
 2256: 
 2257:         Returns
 2258:         -------
 2259:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2260:             Drawn samples from the parameterized power distribution.
 2261: 
 2262:         Raises
 2263:         ------
 2264:         ValueError
 2265:             If a < 1.
 2266: 
 2267:         Notes
 2268:         -----
 2269:         The probability density function is
 2270: 
 2271:         .. math:: P(x; a) = ax^{a-1}, 0 \\le x \\le 1, a>0.
 2272: 
 2273:         The power function distribution is just the inverse of the Pareto
 2274:         distribution. It may also be seen as a special case of the Beta
 2275:         distribution.
 2276: 
 2277:         It is used, for example, in modeling the over-reporting of insurance
 2278:         claims.
 2279: 
 2280:         References
 2281:         ----------
 2282:         .. [1] Christian Kleiber, Samuel Kotz, "Statistical size distributions
 2283:                in economics and actuarial sciences", Wiley, 2003.
 2284:         .. [2] Heckert, N. A. and Filliben, James J. "NIST Handbook 148:
 2285:                Dataplot Reference Manual, Volume 2: Let Subcommands and Library
 2286:                Functions", National Institute of Standards and Technology
 2287:                Handbook Series, June 2003.
 2288:                https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/software/dataplot/refman2/auxillar/powpdf.pdf
 2289: 
 2290:         Examples
 2291:         --------
 2292:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 2293: 
 2294:         >>> a = 5. # shape
 2295:         >>> samples = 1000
 2296:         >>> s = np.random.power(a, samples)
 2297: 
 2298:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 2299:         the probability density function:
 2300: 
 2301:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2302:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, bins=30)
 2303:         >>> x = np.linspace(0, 1, 100)
 2304:         >>> y = a*x**(a-1.)
 2305:         >>> normed_y = samples*np.diff(bins)[0]*y
 2306:         >>> plt.plot(x, normed_y)
 2307:         >>> plt.show()
 2308: 
 2309:         Compare the power function distribution to the inverse of the Pareto.
 2310: 
 2311:         >>> from scipy import stats # doctest: +SKIP
 2312:         >>> rvs = np.random.power(5, 1000000)
 2313:         >>> rvsp = np.random.pareto(5, 1000000)
 2314:         >>> xx = np.linspace(0,1,100)

 2320:         >>> plt.title('np.random.power(5)')

+2338:     def laplace(self, loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_71laplace(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_70laplace[] = "\n        laplace(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from the Laplace or double exponential distribution with\n        specified location (or mean) and scale (decay).\n\n        The Laplace distribution is similar to the Gaussian/normal distribution,\n        but is sharper at the peak and has fatter tails. It represents the\n        difference between two independent, identically distributed exponential\n        random variables.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        loc : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            The position, :math:`\\mu`, of the distribution peak. Default is 0.\n        scale : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            :math:`\\lambda`, the exponential decay. Default is 1. Must be non-\n            negative.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``loc`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(loc, scale).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Laplace distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        It has the probability density function\n\n        .. math:: f(x; \\mu, \\lambda) = \\frac{1}{2\\lambda}\n                                       \\exp\\left(-\\frac{|x - \\mu|}{\\lambda}\\right).\n\n        The first law of Laplace, from 1774, states that the frequency\n        of an error can be expressed as an exponential function of the\n        absolute magnitude of the error, which leads to the Laplace\n        distribution. For many problems in economics and health\n        sciences, this distribution seems to model the data better\n        than the standard Gaussian distribution.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Abramowitz, ""M. and Stegun, I. A. (Eds.). \"Handbook of\n               Mathematical Functions with Formulas, Graphs, and Mathematical\n               Tables, 9th printing,\" New York: Dover, 1972.\n        .. [2] Kotz, Samuel, et. al. \"The Laplace Distribution and\n               Generalizations, \" Birkhauser, 2001.\n        .. [3] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Laplace Distribution.\"\n               From MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.\n               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/LaplaceDistribution.html\n        .. [4] Wikipedia, \"Laplace distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laplace_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution\n\n        >>> loc, scale = 0., 1.\n        >>> s = np.random.laplace(loc, scale, 1000)\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 30, density=True)\n        >>> x = np.arange(-8., 8., .01)\n        >>> pdf = np.exp(-abs(x-loc)/scale)/(2.*scale)\n        >>> plt.plot(x, pdf)\n\n        Plot Gaussian for comparison:\n\n        >>> g = (1/(scale * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi)) *\n        ...      np.exp(-(x - loc)**2 / (2 * scale**2)))\n        >>> plt.plot(x,g)\n\n        ";
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_71laplace(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds) {
  PyObject *__pyx_v_loc = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_v_scale = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_v_size = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_r = 0;
  __Pyx_RefNannyDeclarations
  __Pyx_RefNannySetupContext("laplace (wrapper)", 0);
  {
    static PyObject **__pyx_pyargnames[] = {&__pyx_n_s_loc,&__pyx_n_s_scale,&__pyx_n_s_size,0};
    PyObject* values[3] = {0,0,0};
    values[0] = ((PyObject *)__pyx_float_0_0);
    values[1] = ((PyObject *)__pyx_float_1_0);
    values[2] = ((PyObject *)Py_None);
    if (unlikely(__pyx_kwds)) {

        case  3: values[2] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 2);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  2: values[1] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 1);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  1: values[0] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 0);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  0: break;
        default: goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;
      }
      kw_args = PyDict_Size(__pyx_kwds);
      switch (pos_args) {
        case  0:
        if (kw_args > 0) {
          PyObject* value = __Pyx_PyDict_GetItemStr(__pyx_kwds, __pyx_n_s_loc);

        }
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;

        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  2:

          PyObject* value = __Pyx_PyDict_GetItemStr(__pyx_kwds, __pyx_n_s_size);
          if (value) { values[2] = value; kw_args--; }
        }
      }
      if (unlikely(kw_args > 0)) {
        if (unlikely(__Pyx_ParseOptionalKeywords(__pyx_kwds, __pyx_pyargnames, 0, values, pos_args, "laplace") < 0)) __PYX_ERR(0, 2338, __pyx_L3_error)
      }
    } else {
      switch (PyTuple_GET_SIZE(__pyx_args)) {
        case  3: values[2] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 2);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  2: values[1] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 1);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  1: values[0] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 0);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  0: break;
        default: goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;
      }
    }
    __pyx_v_loc = values[0];
    __pyx_v_scale = values[1];
    __pyx_v_size = values[2];
  }
  goto __pyx_L4_argument_unpacking_done;
  __pyx_L5_argtuple_error:;
  __Pyx_RaiseArgtupleInvalid("laplace", 0, 0, 3, PyTuple_GET_SIZE(__pyx_args)); __PYX_ERR(0, 2338, __pyx_L3_error)
  __pyx_L3_error:;
  __Pyx_AddTraceback("randomgen.mtrand.RandomState.laplace", __pyx_clineno, __pyx_lineno, __pyx_filename);
  __Pyx_RefNannyFinishContext();
  return NULL;
  __pyx_L4_argument_unpacking_done:;

 2339:         """
 2340:         laplace(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None)
 2341: 
 2342:         Draw samples from the Laplace or double exponential distribution with
 2343:         specified location (or mean) and scale (decay).
 2344: 
 2345:         The Laplace distribution is similar to the Gaussian/normal distribution,
 2346:         but is sharper at the peak and has fatter tails. It represents the
 2347:         difference between two independent, identically distributed exponential
 2348:         random variables.
 2349: 
 2350:         Parameters
 2351:         ----------
 2352:         loc : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2353:             The position, :math:`\\mu`, of the distribution peak. Default is 0.
 2354:         scale : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2355:             :math:`\\lambda`, the exponential decay. Default is 1. Must be non-
 2356:             negative.
 2357:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2358:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2359:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2360:             a single value is returned if ``loc`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.
 2361:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(loc, scale).size`` samples are drawn.
 2362: 
 2363:         Returns
 2364:         -------
 2365:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2366:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Laplace distribution.
 2367: 
 2368:         Notes
 2369:         -----
 2370:         It has the probability density function
 2371: 
 2372:         .. math:: f(x; \\mu, \\lambda) = \\frac{1}{2\\lambda}
 2373:                                        \\exp\\left(-\\frac{|x - \\mu|}{\\lambda}\\right).
 2374: 
 2375:         The first law of Laplace, from 1774, states that the frequency
 2376:         of an error can be expressed as an exponential function of the
 2377:         absolute magnitude of the error, which leads to the Laplace
 2378:         distribution. For many problems in economics and health
 2379:         sciences, this distribution seems to model the data better
 2380:         than the standard Gaussian distribution.
 2381: 
 2382:         References
 2383:         ----------
 2384:         .. [1] Abramowitz, M. and Stegun, I. A. (Eds.). "Handbook of
 2385:                Mathematical Functions with Formulas, Graphs, and Mathematical
 2386:                Tables, 9th printing," New York: Dover, 1972.
 2387:         .. [2] Kotz, Samuel, et. al. "The Laplace Distribution and
 2388:                Generalizations, " Birkhauser, 2001.
 2389:         .. [3] Weisstein, Eric W. "Laplace Distribution."
 2390:                From MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.
 2391:                https://mathworld.wolfram.com/LaplaceDistribution.html
 2392:         .. [4] Wikipedia, "Laplace distribution",
 2393:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laplace_distribution
 2394: 
 2395:         Examples
 2396:         --------
 2397:         Draw samples from the distribution
 2398: 
 2399:         >>> loc, scale = 0., 1.
 2400:         >>> s = np.random.laplace(loc, scale, 1000)
 2401: 
 2402:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 2403:         the probability density function:
 2404: 
 2405:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2406:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 30, density=True)
 2407:         >>> x = np.arange(-8., 8., .01)
 2408:         >>> pdf = np.exp(-abs(x-loc)/scale)/(2.*scale)
 2409:         >>> plt.plot(x, pdf)
 2410: 
 2411:         Plot Gaussian for comparison:
 2412: 
 2413:         >>> g = (1/(scale * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi)) *
 2414:         ...      np.exp(-(x - loc)**2 / (2 * scale**2)))
 2415:         >>> plt.plot(x,g)
 2416: 
 2417:         """
+2418:         return cont(&random_laplace, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 2,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&random_laplace), (&__pyx_v_self->_bitgen), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 2, __pyx_v_loc, __pyx_n_u_loc, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_v_scale, __pyx_n_u_scale, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NON_NEGATIVE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 2418, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 2419:                     loc, "loc", CONS_NONE,
 2420:                     scale, "scale", CONS_NON_NEGATIVE,
 2421:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE, None)
 2422: 
+2423:     def gumbel(self, loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_73gumbel(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_72gumbel[] = "\n        gumbel(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Gumbel distribution.\n\n        Draw samples from a Gumbel distribution with specified location and\n        scale. For more information on the Gumbel distribution, see\n        Notes and References below.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        loc : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            The location of the mode of the distribution. Default is 0.\n        scale : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            The scale parameter of the distribution. Default is 1. Must be non-\n            negative.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``loc`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(loc, scale).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Gumbel distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.gumbel_l\n        scipy.stats.gumbel_r\n        scipy.stats.genextreme\n        weibull\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The Gumbel (or Smallest Extreme Value (SEV) or the Smallest Extreme\n        Value Type I) distribution is one of a class of Generalized Extreme\n        Value (GEV) distributions used in modeling extreme value problems.\n        The Gumbel is a special case of the Extreme Value Type I distribution\n        for maximums from distributions with \"exponential-like\" tails.\n\n        The probability density for the Gumbel distribution is\n\n        .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{e^{-(x - \\mu)/ \\beta}}{\\beta} e^{ -e^{-(x - \\mu)/\n                  \\beta}},\n\n        where :math:`\\mu` is the mode, a location parameter, and\n        :math:`\\beta` is the scale parameter.\n\n        The Gumbel"" (named for German mathematician Emil Julius Gumbel) was used\n        very early in the hydrology literature, for modeling the occurrence of\n        flood events. It is also used for modeling maximum wind speed and\n        rainfall rates. It is a \"fat-tailed\" distribution - the probability of\n        an event in the tail of the distribution is larger than if one used a\n        Gaussian, hence the surprisingly frequent occurrence of 100-year\n        floods. Floods were initially modeled as a Gaussian process, which\n        underestimated the frequency of extreme events.\n\n        It is one of a class of extreme value distributions, the Generalized\n        Extreme Value (GEV) distributions, which also includes the Weibull and\n        Frechet.\n\n        The function has a mean of :math:`\\mu + 0.57721\\beta` and a variance\n        of :math:`\\frac{\\pi^2}{6}\\beta^2`.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Gumbel, E. J., \"Statistics of Extremes,\"\n               New York: Columbia University Press, 1958.\n        .. [2] Reiss, R.-D. and Thomas, M., \"Statistical Analysis of Extreme\n               Values from Insurance, Finance, Hydrology and Other Fields,\"\n               Basel: Birkhauser Verlag, 2001.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> mu, beta = 0, 0.1 # location and scale\n        >>> s = np.random.gumbel(mu, beta, 1000)\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 30, density=True)\n        >>> plt.plot(bins, (1/beta)*np.exp(-(bins - mu)/beta)\n        ...          * np.exp( -np.exp( -(bins - mu) /beta) ),\n        ...          linewidth=2, color='r')\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        Show how an extreme value distribution can arise from a Gaussian process\n        and compare to a Gaussian:\n\n        >>> means = ""[]\n        >>> maxima = []\n        >>> for i in range(0,1000) :\n        ...    a = np.random.normal(mu, beta, 1000)\n        ...    means.append(a.mean())\n        ...    maxima.append(a.max())\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(maxima, 30, density=True)\n        >>> beta = np.std(maxima) * np.sqrt(6) / np.pi\n        >>> mu = np.mean(maxima) - 0.57721*beta\n        >>> plt.plot(bins, (1/beta)*np.exp(-(bins - mu)/beta)\n        ...          * np.exp(-np.exp(-(bins - mu)/beta)),\n        ...          linewidth=2, color='r')\n        >>> plt.plot(bins, 1/(beta * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi))\n        ...          * np.exp(-(bins - mu)**2 / (2 * beta**2)),\n        ...          linewidth=2, color='g')\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 2424:         """
 2425:         gumbel(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None)
 2426: 
 2427:         Draw samples from a Gumbel distribution.
 2428: 
 2429:         Draw samples from a Gumbel distribution with specified location and
 2430:         scale. For more information on the Gumbel distribution, see
 2431:         Notes and References below.
 2432: 
 2433:         Parameters
 2434:         ----------
 2435:         loc : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2436:             The location of the mode of the distribution. Default is 0.
 2437:         scale : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2438:             The scale parameter of the distribution. Default is 1. Must be non-
 2439:             negative.
 2440:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2441:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2442:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2443:             a single value is returned if ``loc`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.
 2444:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(loc, scale).size`` samples are drawn.
 2445: 
 2446:         Returns
 2447:         -------
 2448:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2449:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Gumbel distribution.
 2450: 
 2451:         See Also
 2452:         --------
 2453:         scipy.stats.gumbel_l
 2454:         scipy.stats.gumbel_r
 2455:         scipy.stats.genextreme
 2456:         weibull
 2457: 
 2458:         Notes
 2459:         -----
 2460:         The Gumbel (or Smallest Extreme Value (SEV) or the Smallest Extreme
 2461:         Value Type I) distribution is one of a class of Generalized Extreme
 2462:         Value (GEV) distributions used in modeling extreme value problems.
 2463:         The Gumbel is a special case of the Extreme Value Type I distribution
 2464:         for maximums from distributions with "exponential-like" tails.
 2465: 
 2466:         The probability density for the Gumbel distribution is
 2467: 
 2468:         .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{e^{-(x - \\mu)/ \\beta}}{\\beta} e^{ -e^{-(x - \\mu)/
 2469:                   \\beta}},
 2470: 
 2471:         where :math:`\\mu` is the mode, a location parameter, and
 2472:         :math:`\\beta` is the scale parameter.
 2473: 
 2474:         The Gumbel (named for German mathematician Emil Julius Gumbel) was used
 2475:         very early in the hydrology literature, for modeling the occurrence of
 2476:         flood events. It is also used for modeling maximum wind speed and
 2477:         rainfall rates. It is a "fat-tailed" distribution - the probability of
 2478:         an event in the tail of the distribution is larger than if one used a
 2479:         Gaussian, hence the surprisingly frequent occurrence of 100-year
 2480:         floods. Floods were initially modeled as a Gaussian process, which
 2481:         underestimated the frequency of extreme events.
 2482: 
 2483:         It is one of a class of extreme value distributions, the Generalized
 2484:         Extreme Value (GEV) distributions, which also includes the Weibull and
 2485:         Frechet.
 2486: 
 2487:         The function has a mean of :math:`\\mu + 0.57721\\beta` and a variance
 2488:         of :math:`\\frac{\\pi^2}{6}\\beta^2`.
 2489: 
 2490:         References
 2491:         ----------
 2492:         .. [1] Gumbel, E. J., "Statistics of Extremes,"
 2493:                New York: Columbia University Press, 1958.
 2494:         .. [2] Reiss, R.-D. and Thomas, M., "Statistical Analysis of Extreme
 2495:                Values from Insurance, Finance, Hydrology and Other Fields,"
 2496:                Basel: Birkhauser Verlag, 2001.
 2497: 
 2498:         Examples
 2499:         --------
 2500:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 2501: 
 2502:         >>> mu, beta = 0, 0.1 # location and scale
 2503:         >>> s = np.random.gumbel(mu, beta, 1000)
 2504: 
 2505:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 2506:         the probability density function:
 2507: 
 2508:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2509:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 30, density=True)
 2510:         >>> plt.plot(bins, (1/beta)*np.exp(-(bins - mu)/beta)
 2511:         ...          * np.exp( -np.exp( -(bins - mu) /beta) ),
 2512:         ...          linewidth=2, color='r')
 2513:         >>> plt.show()
 2514: 
 2515:         Show how an extreme value distribution can arise from a Gaussian process
 2516:         and compare to a Gaussian:
 2517: 
 2518:         >>> means = []
 2519:         >>> maxima = []
 2520:         >>> for i in range(0,1000) :
 2521:         ...    a = np.random.normal(mu, beta, 1000)
 2522:         ...    means.append(a.mean())
 2523:         ...    maxima.append(a.max())
 2524:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(maxima, 30, density=True)
 2525:         >>> beta = np.std(maxima) * np.sqrt(6) / np.pi
 2526:         >>> mu = np.mean(maxima) - 0.57721*beta
 2527:         >>> plt.plot(bins, (1/beta)*np.exp(-(bins - mu)/beta)
 2528:         ...          * np.exp(-np.exp(-(bins - mu)/beta)),
 2529:         ...          linewidth=2, color='r')
 2530:         >>> plt.plot(bins, 1/(beta * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi))
 2531:         ...          * np.exp(-(bins - mu)**2 / (2 * beta**2)),
 2532:         ...          linewidth=2, color='g')
 2533:         >>> plt.show()
 2534: 
 2535:         """
+2536:         return cont(&random_gumbel, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 2,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&random_gumbel), (&__pyx_v_self->_bitgen), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 2, __pyx_v_loc, __pyx_n_u_loc, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_v_scale, __pyx_n_u_scale, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NON_NEGATIVE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 2536, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 2537:                     loc, "loc", CONS_NONE,
 2538:                     scale, "scale", CONS_NON_NEGATIVE,
 2539:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE, None)
 2540: 
+2541:     def logistic(self, loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_75logistic(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_74logistic[] = "\n        logistic(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a logistic distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a logistic distribution with specified\n        parameters, loc (location or mean, also median), and scale (>0).\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        loc : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            Parameter of the distribution. Default is 0.\n        scale : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            Parameter of the distribution. Must be non-negative.\n            Default is 1.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``loc`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(loc, scale).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized logistic distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.logistic : probability density function, distribution or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density for the Logistic distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(x) = P(x) = \\frac{e^{-(x-\\mu)/s}}{s(1+e^{-(x-\\mu)/s})^2},\n\n        where :math:`\\mu` = location and :math:`s` = scale.\n\n        The Logistic distribution is used in Extreme Value problems where it\n        can act as a mixture of Gumbel distributions, in Epidemiology, and by\n        the World Chess Federation (FIDE) where it is used in the Elo ranking\n        system, assuming the performance of each player is a logistically\n        distributed random variable.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Reiss, R.-D. and Thomas M. (2001), \"Statistical Analysis of\n               Extreme Values, from Insurance, Finance, Hydrol""ogy and Other\n               Fields,\" Birkhauser Verlag, Basel, pp 132-133.\n        .. [2] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Logistic Distribution.\" From\n               MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.\n               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/LogisticDistribution.html\n        .. [3] Wikipedia, \"Logistic-distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> loc, scale = 10, 1\n        >>> s = np.random.logistic(loc, scale, 10000)\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, bins=50)\n\n        #   plot against distribution\n\n        >>> def logist(x, loc, scale):\n        ...     return np.exp((loc-x)/scale)/(scale*(1+np.exp((loc-x)/scale))**2)\n        >>> lgst_val = logist(bins, loc, scale)\n        >>> plt.plot(bins, lgst_val * count.max() / lgst_val.max())\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 2542:         """
 2543:         logistic(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None)
 2544: 
 2545:         Draw samples from a logistic distribution.
 2546: 
 2547:         Samples are drawn from a logistic distribution with specified
 2548:         parameters, loc (location or mean, also median), and scale (>0).
 2549: 
 2550:         Parameters
 2551:         ----------
 2552:         loc : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2553:             Parameter of the distribution. Default is 0.
 2554:         scale : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2555:             Parameter of the distribution. Must be non-negative.
 2556:             Default is 1.
 2557:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2558:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2559:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2560:             a single value is returned if ``loc`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.
 2561:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(loc, scale).size`` samples are drawn.
 2562: 
 2563:         Returns
 2564:         -------
 2565:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2566:             Drawn samples from the parameterized logistic distribution.
 2567: 
 2568:         See Also
 2569:         --------
 2570:         scipy.stats.logistic : probability density function, distribution or
 2571:             cumulative density function, etc.
 2572: 
 2573:         Notes
 2574:         -----
 2575:         The probability density for the Logistic distribution is
 2576: 
 2577:         .. math:: P(x) = P(x) = \\frac{e^{-(x-\\mu)/s}}{s(1+e^{-(x-\\mu)/s})^2},
 2578: 
 2579:         where :math:`\\mu` = location and :math:`s` = scale.
 2580: 
 2581:         The Logistic distribution is used in Extreme Value problems where it
 2582:         can act as a mixture of Gumbel distributions, in Epidemiology, and by
 2583:         the World Chess Federation (FIDE) where it is used in the Elo ranking
 2584:         system, assuming the performance of each player is a logistically
 2585:         distributed random variable.
 2586: 
 2587:         References
 2588:         ----------
 2589:         .. [1] Reiss, R.-D. and Thomas M. (2001), "Statistical Analysis of
 2590:                Extreme Values, from Insurance, Finance, Hydrology and Other
 2591:                Fields," Birkhauser Verlag, Basel, pp 132-133.
 2592:         .. [2] Weisstein, Eric W. "Logistic Distribution." From
 2593:                MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.
 2594:                https://mathworld.wolfram.com/LogisticDistribution.html
 2595:         .. [3] Wikipedia, "Logistic-distribution",
 2596:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_distribution
 2597: 
 2598:         Examples
 2599:         --------
 2600:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 2601: 
 2602:         >>> loc, scale = 10, 1
 2603:         >>> s = np.random.logistic(loc, scale, 10000)
 2604:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2605:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, bins=50)
 2606: 
 2607:         #   plot against distribution
 2608: 
 2609:         >>> def logist(x, loc, scale):
 2610:         ...     return np.exp((loc-x)/scale)/(scale*(1+np.exp((loc-x)/scale))**2)
 2611:         >>> lgst_val = logist(bins, loc, scale)
 2612:         >>> plt.plot(bins, lgst_val * count.max() / lgst_val.max())
 2613:         >>> plt.show()
 2614: 
 2615:         """
+2616:         return cont(&random_logistic, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 2,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&random_logistic), (&__pyx_v_self->_bitgen), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 2, __pyx_v_loc, __pyx_n_u_loc, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_v_scale, __pyx_n_u_scale, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NON_NEGATIVE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 2616, __pyx_L1_error)

  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 2617:                     loc, "loc", CONS_NONE,
 2618:                     scale, "scale", CONS_NON_NEGATIVE,
 2619:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE, None)
 2620: 
+2621:     def lognormal(self, mean=0.0, sigma=1.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_77lognormal(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_76lognormal[] = "\n        lognormal(mean=0.0, sigma=1.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a log-normal distribution.\n\n        Draw samples from a log-normal distribution with specified mean,\n        standard deviation, and array shape. Note that the mean and standard\n        deviation are not the values for the distribution itself, but of the\n        underlying normal distribution it is derived from.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        mean : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            Mean value of the underlying normal distribution. Default is 0.\n        sigma : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            Standard deviation of the underlying normal distribution. Must be\n            non-negative. Default is 1.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``mean`` and ``sigma`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(mean, sigma).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized log-normal distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.lognorm : probability density function, distribution,\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        A variable `x` has a log-normal distribution if `log(x)` is normally\n        distributed. The probability density function for the log-normal\n        distribution is:\n\n        .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{1}{\\sigma x \\sqrt{2\\pi}}\n                         e^{(-\\frac{(ln(x)-\\mu)^2}{2\\sigma^2})}\n\n        where :math:`\\mu` is the mean and :math:`\\sigma` is the standard\n        deviation of the normally distributed logarithm of the variable.\n        A log-normal distribution results if a random variable is the *product*\n       "" of a large number of independent, identically-distributed variables in\n        the same way that a normal distribution results if the variable is the\n        *sum* of a large number of independent, identically-distributed\n        variables.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Limpert, E., Stahel, W. A., and Abbt, M., \"Log-normal\n               Distributions across the Sciences: Keys and Clues,\"\n               BioScience, Vol. 51, No. 5, May, 2001.\n               https://stat.ethz.ch/~stahel/lognormal/bioscience.pdf\n        .. [2] Reiss, R.D. and Thomas, M., \"Statistical Analysis of Extreme\n               Values,\" Basel: Birkhauser Verlag, 2001, pp. 31-32.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> mu, sigma = 3., 1. # mean and standard deviation\n        >>> s = np.random.lognormal(mu, sigma, 1000)\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 100, density=True, align='mid')\n\n        >>> x = np.linspace(min(bins), max(bins), 10000)\n        >>> pdf = (np.exp(-(np.log(x) - mu)**2 / (2 * sigma**2))\n        ...        / (x * sigma * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi)))\n\n        >>> plt.plot(x, pdf, linewidth=2, color='r')\n        >>> plt.axis('tight')\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        Demonstrate that taking the products of random samples from a uniform\n        distribution can be fit well by a log-normal probability density\n        function.\n\n        >>> # Generate a thousand samples: each is the product of 100 random\n        >>> # values, drawn from a normal distribution.\n        >>> b = []\n        >>> for i in range(1000):\n        ...    a = 10. + np.random.standard_normal(100)\n        ...    b.append(np.product(a))\n\n        >>> b = np.array(b) / np.min(b) # scale values to be positive\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.h""ist(b, 100, density=True, align='mid')\n        >>> sigma = np.std(np.log(b))\n        >>> mu = np.mean(np.log(b))\n\n        >>> x = np.linspace(min(bins), max(bins), 10000)\n        >>> pdf = (np.exp(-(np.log(x) - mu)**2 / (2 * sigma**2))\n        ...        / (x * sigma * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi)))\n\n        >>> plt.plot(x, pdf, color='r', linewidth=2)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 2622:         """
 2623:         lognormal(mean=0.0, sigma=1.0, size=None)
 2624: 
 2625:         Draw samples from a log-normal distribution.
 2626: 
 2627:         Draw samples from a log-normal distribution with specified mean,
 2628:         standard deviation, and array shape. Note that the mean and standard
 2629:         deviation are not the values for the distribution itself, but of the
 2630:         underlying normal distribution it is derived from.
 2631: 
 2632:         Parameters
 2633:         ----------
 2634:         mean : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2635:             Mean value of the underlying normal distribution. Default is 0.
 2636:         sigma : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2637:             Standard deviation of the underlying normal distribution. Must be
 2638:             non-negative. Default is 1.
 2639:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2640:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2641:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2642:             a single value is returned if ``mean`` and ``sigma`` are both scalars.
 2643:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(mean, sigma).size`` samples are drawn.
 2644: 
 2645:         Returns
 2646:         -------
 2647:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2648:             Drawn samples from the parameterized log-normal distribution.
 2649: 
 2650:         See Also
 2651:         --------
 2652:         scipy.stats.lognorm : probability density function, distribution,
 2653:             cumulative density function, etc.
 2654: 
 2655:         Notes
 2656:         -----
 2657:         A variable `x` has a log-normal distribution if `log(x)` is normally
 2658:         distributed. The probability density function for the log-normal
 2659:         distribution is:
 2660: 
 2661:         .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{1}{\\sigma x \\sqrt{2\\pi}}
 2662:                          e^{(-\\frac{(ln(x)-\\mu)^2}{2\\sigma^2})}
 2663: 
 2664:         where :math:`\\mu` is the mean and :math:`\\sigma` is the standard
 2665:         deviation of the normally distributed logarithm of the variable.
 2666:         A log-normal distribution results if a random variable is the *product*
 2667:         of a large number of independent, identically-distributed variables in
 2668:         the same way that a normal distribution results if the variable is the
 2669:         *sum* of a large number of independent, identically-distributed
 2670:         variables.
 2671: 
 2672:         References
 2673:         ----------
 2674:         .. [1] Limpert, E., Stahel, W. A., and Abbt, M., "Log-normal
 2675:                Distributions across the Sciences: Keys and Clues,"
 2676:                BioScience, Vol. 51, No. 5, May, 2001.
 2677:                https://stat.ethz.ch/~stahel/lognormal/bioscience.pdf
 2678:         .. [2] Reiss, R.D. and Thomas, M., "Statistical Analysis of Extreme
 2679:                Values," Basel: Birkhauser Verlag, 2001, pp. 31-32.
 2680: 
 2681:         Examples
 2682:         --------
 2683:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 2684: 
 2685:         >>> mu, sigma = 3., 1. # mean and standard deviation
 2686:         >>> s = np.random.lognormal(mu, sigma, 1000)
 2687: 
 2688:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 2689:         the probability density function:
 2690: 
 2691:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2692:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 100, density=True, align='mid')
 2693: 
 2694:         >>> x = np.linspace(min(bins), max(bins), 10000)
 2695:         >>> pdf = (np.exp(-(np.log(x) - mu)**2 / (2 * sigma**2))
 2696:         ...        / (x * sigma * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi)))
 2697: 
 2698:         >>> plt.plot(x, pdf, linewidth=2, color='r')
 2699:         >>> plt.axis('tight')
 2700:         >>> plt.show()
 2701: 
 2702:         Demonstrate that taking the products of random samples from a uniform
 2703:         distribution can be fit well by a log-normal probability density
 2704:         function.
 2705: 
 2706:         >>> # Generate a thousand samples: each is the product of 100 random
 2707:         >>> # values, drawn from a normal distribution.
 2708:         >>> b = []
 2709:         >>> for i in range(1000):
 2710:         ...    a = 10. + np.random.standard_normal(100)
 2711:         ...    b.append(np.product(a))
 2712: 
 2713:         >>> b = np.array(b) / np.min(b) # scale values to be positive
 2714:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(b, 100, density=True, align='mid')
 2715:         >>> sigma = np.std(np.log(b))
 2716:         >>> mu = np.mean(np.log(b))
 2717: 
 2718:         >>> x = np.linspace(min(bins), max(bins), 10000)
 2719:         >>> pdf = (np.exp(-(np.log(x) - mu)**2 / (2 * sigma**2))
 2720:         ...        / (x * sigma * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi)))
 2721: 
 2722:         >>> plt.plot(x, pdf, color='r', linewidth=2)
 2723:         >>> plt.show()
 2724: 
 2725:         """
+2726:         return cont(&legacy_lognormal, &self._aug_state, size, self.lock, 2,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&legacy_lognormal), (&__pyx_v_self->_aug_state), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 2, __pyx_v_mean, __pyx_n_u_mean, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_v_sigma, __pyx_n_u_sigma, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NON_NEGATIVE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 2726, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 2727:                     mean, "mean", CONS_NONE,
 2728:                     sigma, "sigma", CONS_NON_NEGATIVE,
 2729:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE, None)
 2730: 
+2731:     def rayleigh(self, scale=1.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_79rayleigh(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_78rayleigh[] = "\n        rayleigh(scale=1.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Rayleigh distribution.\n\n        The :math:`\\chi` and Weibull distributions are generalizations of the\n        Rayleigh.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        scale : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            Scale, also equals the mode. Must be non-negative. Default is 1.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``scale`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(scale).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Rayleigh distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density function for the Rayleigh distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(x;scale) = \\frac{x}{scale^2}e^{\\frac{-x^2}{2 \\cdotp scale^2}}\n\n        The Rayleigh distribution would arise, for example, if the East\n        and North components of the wind velocity had identical zero-mean\n        Gaussian distributions. Then the wind speed would have a Rayleigh\n        distribution.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Brighton Webs Ltd., \"Rayleigh Distribution,\"\n               https://web.archive.org/web/20090514091424/http://brighton-webs.co.uk:80/distributions/rayleigh.asp\n        .. [2] Wikipedia, \"Rayleigh distribution\"\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rayleigh_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw values from the distribution and plot the histogram\n\n        >>> from matplotlib.pyplot import hist\n        >>> values = hist(np.random.rayleigh(3, 100000), bins=200, density=True)\n\n        Wave heights tend to follow a Rayleigh distribution. If the mean wave\n        height is 1 meter, what fraction of wave""s are likely to be larger than 3\n        meters?\n\n        >>> meanvalue = 1\n        >>> modevalue = np.sqrt(2 / np.pi) * meanvalue\n        >>> s = np.random.rayleigh(modevalue, 1000000)\n\n        The percentage of waves larger than 3 meters is:\n\n        >>> 100.*sum(s>3)/1000000.\n        0.087300000000000003 # random\n\n        ";

 2732:         """
 2733:         rayleigh(scale=1.0, size=None)
 2734: 
 2735:         Draw samples from a Rayleigh distribution.
 2736: 
 2737:         The :math:`\\chi` and Weibull distributions are generalizations of the
 2738:         Rayleigh.
 2739: 
 2740:         Parameters
 2741:         ----------
 2742:         scale : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2743:             Scale, also equals the mode. Must be non-negative. Default is 1.
 2744:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2745:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2746:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2747:             a single value is returned if ``scale`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 2748:             ``np.array(scale).size`` samples are drawn.
 2749: 
 2750:         Returns
 2751:         -------
 2752:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2753:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Rayleigh distribution.
 2754: 
 2755:         Notes
 2756:         -----
 2757:         The probability density function for the Rayleigh distribution is
 2758: 
 2759:         .. math:: P(x;scale) = \\frac{x}{scale^2}e^{\\frac{-x^2}{2 \\cdotp scale^2}}
 2760: 
 2761:         The Rayleigh distribution would arise, for example, if the East
 2762:         and North components of the wind velocity had identical zero-mean
 2763:         Gaussian distributions. Then the wind speed would have a Rayleigh
 2764:         distribution.
 2765: 
 2766:         References
 2767:         ----------
 2768:         .. [1] Brighton Webs Ltd., "Rayleigh Distribution,"
 2769:                https://web.archive.org/web/20090514091424/http://brighton-webs.co.uk:80/distributions/rayleigh.asp
 2770:         .. [2] Wikipedia, "Rayleigh distribution"
 2771:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rayleigh_distribution
 2772: 
 2773:         Examples
 2774:         --------
 2775:         Draw values from the distribution and plot the histogram
 2776: 
 2777:         >>> from matplotlib.pyplot import hist
 2778:         >>> values = hist(np.random.rayleigh(3, 100000), bins=200, density=True)
 2779: 
 2780:         Wave heights tend to follow a Rayleigh distribution. If the mean wave
 2781:         height is 1 meter, what fraction of waves are likely to be larger than 3
 2782:         meters?
 2783: 
 2784:         >>> meanvalue = 1
 2785:         >>> modevalue = np.sqrt(2 / np.pi) * meanvalue
 2786:         >>> s = np.random.rayleigh(modevalue, 1000000)
 2787: 
 2788:         The percentage of waves larger than 3 meters is:
 2789: 
 2790:         >>> 100.*sum(s>3)/1000000.
 2791:         0.087300000000000003 # random
 2792: 
 2793:         """
+2794:         return cont(&random_rayleigh, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 1,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */

 2796:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE,

+2799:     def wald(self, mean, scale, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_81wald(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_80wald[] = "\n        wald(mean, scale, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Wald, or inverse Gaussian, distribution.\n\n        As the scale approaches infinity, the distribution becomes more like a\n        Gaussian. Some references claim that the Wald is an inverse Gaussian\n        with mean equal to 1, but this is by no means universal.\n\n        The inverse Gaussian distribution was first studied in relationship to\n        Brownian motion. In 1956 M.C.K. Tweedie used the name inverse Gaussian\n        because there is an inverse relationship between the time to cover a\n        unit distance and distance covered in unit time.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        mean : float or array_like of floats\n            Distribution mean, must be > 0.\n        scale : float or array_like of floats\n            Scale parameter, must be > 0.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``mean`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(mean, scale).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Wald distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density function for the Wald distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(x;mean,scale) = \\sqrt{\\frac{scale}{2\\pi x^3}}e^\n                                    \\frac{-scale(x-mean)^2}{2\\cdotp mean^2x}\n\n        As noted above the inverse Gaussian distribution first arise\n        from attempts to model Brownian motion. It is also a\n        competitor to the Weibull for use in reliability modeling and\n        modeling stock returns and interest rate processes.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Brighton Webs Ltd., Wald Distribution,\n               https:""//web.archive.org/web/20090423014010/http://www.brighton-webs.co.uk:80/distributions/wald.asp\n        .. [2] Chhikara, Raj S., and Folks, J. Leroy, \"The Inverse Gaussian\n               Distribution: Theory : Methodology, and Applications\", CRC Press,\n               1988.\n        .. [3] Wikipedia, \"Inverse Gaussian distribution\"\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_Gaussian_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw values from the distribution and plot the histogram:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> h = plt.hist(np.random.wald(3, 2, 100000), bins=200, density=True)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_81wald(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds) {

        case  3: values[2] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 2);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;

 2800:         """
 2801:         wald(mean, scale, size=None)
 2802: 
 2803:         Draw samples from a Wald, or inverse Gaussian, distribution.
 2804: 
 2805:         As the scale approaches infinity, the distribution becomes more like a
 2806:         Gaussian. Some references claim that the Wald is an inverse Gaussian
 2807:         with mean equal to 1, but this is by no means universal.
 2808: 
 2809:         The inverse Gaussian distribution was first studied in relationship to
 2810:         Brownian motion. In 1956 M.C.K. Tweedie used the name inverse Gaussian
 2811:         because there is an inverse relationship between the time to cover a
 2812:         unit distance and distance covered in unit time.
 2813: 
 2814:         Parameters
 2815:         ----------
 2816:         mean : float or array_like of floats
 2817:             Distribution mean, must be > 0.
 2818:         scale : float or array_like of floats
 2819:             Scale parameter, must be > 0.
 2820:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2821:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2822:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2823:             a single value is returned if ``mean`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.
 2824:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(mean, scale).size`` samples are drawn.
 2825: 
 2826:         Returns
 2827:         -------
 2828:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2829:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Wald distribution.
 2830: 
 2831:         Notes
 2832:         -----
 2833:         The probability density function for the Wald distribution is
 2834: 
 2835:         .. math:: P(x;mean,scale) = \\sqrt{\\frac{scale}{2\\pi x^3}}e^
 2836:                                     \\frac{-scale(x-mean)^2}{2\\cdotp mean^2x}
 2837: 
 2838:         As noted above the inverse Gaussian distribution first arise
 2839:         from attempts to model Brownian motion. It is also a
 2840:         competitor to the Weibull for use in reliability modeling and
 2841:         modeling stock returns and interest rate processes.
 2842: 
 2843:         References
 2844:         ----------
 2845:         .. [1] Brighton Webs Ltd., Wald Distribution,
 2846:                https://web.archive.org/web/20090423014010/http://www.brighton-webs.co.uk:80/distributions/wald.asp
 2847:         .. [2] Chhikara, Raj S., and Folks, J. Leroy, "The Inverse Gaussian
 2848:                Distribution: Theory : Methodology, and Applications", CRC Press,
 2849:                1988.
 2850:         .. [3] Wikipedia, "Inverse Gaussian distribution"
 2851:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_Gaussian_distribution
 2852: 
 2853:         Examples
 2854:         --------
 2855:         Draw values from the distribution and plot the histogram:
 2856: 
 2857:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2858:         >>> h = plt.hist(np.random.wald(3, 2, 100000), bins=200, density=True)
 2859:         >>> plt.show()
 2860:

+2867:     def triangular(self, left, mode, right, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_83triangular(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_82triangular[] = "\n        triangular(left, mode, right, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from the triangular distribution over the\n        interval ``[left, right]``.\n\n        The triangular distribution is a continuous probability\n        distribution with lower limit left, peak at mode, and upper\n        limit right. Unlike the other distributions, these parameters\n        directly define the shape of the pdf.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        left : float or array_like of floats\n            Lower limit.\n        mode : float or array_like of floats\n            The value where the peak of the distribution occurs.\n            The value must fulfill the condition ``left <= mode <= right``.\n        right : float or array_like of floats\n            Upper limit, must be larger than `left`.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``left``, ``mode``, and ``right``\n            are all scalars. Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(left, mode, right).size``\n            samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized triangular distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density function for the triangular distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(x;l, m, r) = \\begin{cases}\n                  \\frac{2(x-l)}{(r-l)(m-l)}& \\text{for $l \\leq x \\leq m$},\\\\\n                  \\frac{2(r-x)}{(r-l)(r-m)}& \\text{for $m \\leq x \\leq r$},\\\\\n                  0& \\text{otherwise}.\n                  \\end{cases}\n\n        The triangular distribution is often used in ill-defined\n        problems where the underlying distribution is not known, but\n        some knowledge of the limits and mode exists. Often it is used\n        in simulations.\n\n        Refere""nces\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Wikipedia, \"Triangular distribution\"\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangular_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw values from the distribution and plot the histogram:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> h = plt.hist(np.random.triangular(-3, 0, 8, 100000), bins=200,\n        ...              density=True)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 2868:         """
 2869:         triangular(left, mode, right, size=None)
 2870: 
 2871:         Draw samples from the triangular distribution over the
 2872:         interval ``[left, right]``.
 2873: 
 2874:         The triangular distribution is a continuous probability
 2875:         distribution with lower limit left, peak at mode, and upper
 2876:         limit right. Unlike the other distributions, these parameters
 2877:         directly define the shape of the pdf.
 2878: 
 2879:         Parameters
 2880:         ----------
 2881:         left : float or array_like of floats
 2882:             Lower limit.
 2883:         mode : float or array_like of floats
 2884:             The value where the peak of the distribution occurs.
 2885:             The value must fulfill the condition ``left <= mode <= right``.
 2886:         right : float or array_like of floats
 2887:             Upper limit, must be larger than `left`.
 2888:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2889:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2890:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2891:             a single value is returned if ``left``, ``mode``, and ``right``
 2892:             are all scalars. Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(left, mode, right).size``
 2893:             samples are drawn.
 2894: 
 2895:         Returns
 2896:         -------
 2897:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2898:             Drawn samples from the parameterized triangular distribution.
 2899: 
 2900:         Notes
 2901:         -----
 2902:         The probability density function for the triangular distribution is
 2903: 
 2904:         .. math:: P(x;l, m, r) = \\begin{cases}
 2905:                   \\frac{2(x-l)}{(r-l)(m-l)}& \\text{for $l \\leq x \\leq m$},\\\\
 2906:                   \\frac{2(r-x)}{(r-l)(r-m)}& \\text{for $m \\leq x \\leq r$},\\\\
 2907:                   0& \\text{otherwise}.
 2908:                   \\end{cases}
 2909: 
 2910:         The triangular distribution is often used in ill-defined
 2911:         problems where the underlying distribution is not known, but
 2912:         some knowledge of the limits and mode exists. Often it is used
 2913:         in simulations.
 2914: 
 2915:         References
 2916:         ----------
 2917:         .. [1] Wikipedia, "Triangular distribution"
 2918:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangular_distribution
 2919: 
 2920:         Examples
 2921:         --------
 2922:         Draw values from the distribution and plot the histogram:
 2923: 
 2924:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2925:         >>> h = plt.hist(np.random.triangular(-3, 0, 8, 100000), bins=200,
 2926:         ...              density=True)
 2927:         >>> plt.show()
 2928: 
 2929:         """
+2930:         cdef bint is_scalar = True
  __pyx_v_is_scalar = 1;
