 2965: 
 2966:     # Complicated, discrete distributions:
+2967:     def binomial(self, n, p, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_85binomial(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_84binomial[] = "\n        binomial(n, p, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a binomial distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a binomial distribution with specified\n        parameters, n trials and p probability of success where\n        n an integer >= 0 and p is in the interval [0,1]. (n may be\n        input as a float, but it is truncated to an integer in use)\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        n : int or array_like of ints\n            Parameter of the distribution, >= 0. Floats are also accepted,\n            but they will be truncated to integers.\n        p : float or array_like of floats\n            Parameter of the distribution, >= 0 and <=1.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``n`` and ``p`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(n, p).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized binomial distribution, where\n            each sample is equal to the number of successes over the n trials.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.binom : probability density function, distribution or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density for the binomial distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(N) = \\binom{n}{N}p^N(1-p)^{n-N},\n\n        where :math:`n` is the number of trials, :math:`p` is the probability\n        of success, and :math:`N` is the number of successes.\n\n        When estimating the standard error of a proportion in a population by\n        using a random sample, the normal distribution works well unless the\n        product p*n <=5, where p = population proportion estimate, and n =\n        number of samples, in which case the binomia""l distribution is used\n        instead. For example, a sample of 15 people shows 4 who are left\n        handed, and 11 who are right handed. Then p = 4/15 = 27%. 0.27*15 = 4,\n        so the binomial distribution should be used in this case.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Dalgaard, Peter, \"Introductory Statistics with R\",\n               Springer-Verlag, 2002.\n        .. [2] Glantz, Stanton A. \"Primer of Biostatistics.\", McGraw-Hill,\n               Fifth Edition, 2002.\n        .. [3] Lentner, Marvin, \"Elementary Applied Statistics\", Bogden\n               and Quigley, 1972.\n        .. [4] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Binomial Distribution.\" From MathWorld--A\n               Wolfram Web Resource.\n               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/BinomialDistribution.html\n        .. [5] Wikipedia, \"Binomial distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binomial_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> n, p = 10, .5  # number of trials, probability of each trial\n        >>> s = np.random.binomial(n, p, 1000)\n        # result of flipping a coin 10 times, tested 1000 times.\n\n        A real world example. A company drills 9 wild-cat oil exploration\n        wells, each with an estimated probability of success of 0.1. All nine\n        wells fail. What is the probability of that happening?\n\n        Let's do 20,000 trials of the model, and count the number that\n        generate zero positive results.\n\n        >>> sum(np.random.binomial(9, 0.1, 20000) == 0)/20000.\n        # answer = 0.38885, or 38%.\n\n        ";
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_85binomial(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds) {
  PyObject *__pyx_v_n = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_v_p = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_v_size = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_r = 0;
  __Pyx_RefNannyDeclarations
  __Pyx_RefNannySetupContext("binomial (wrapper)", 0);
  {
    static PyObject **__pyx_pyargnames[] = {&__pyx_n_s_n,&__pyx_n_s_p,&__pyx_n_s_size,0};
    PyObject* values[3] = {0,0,0};
    values[2] = ((PyObject *)Py_None);
    if (unlikely(__pyx_kwds)) {
      Py_ssize_t kw_args;
      const Py_ssize_t pos_args = PyTuple_GET_SIZE(__pyx_args);
      switch (pos_args) {
        case  3: values[2] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 2);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  2: values[1] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 1);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  1: values[0] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 0);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  0: break;
        default: goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;
      }
      kw_args = PyDict_Size(__pyx_kwds);
      switch (pos_args) {
        case  0:
        if (likely((values[0] = __Pyx_PyDict_GetItemStr(__pyx_kwds, __pyx_n_s_n)) != 0)) kw_args--;
        else goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  1:

        else {

        }

        values[0] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 0);
        break;
        default: goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;
      }

    __pyx_v_n = values[0];

    __pyx_v_size = values[2];

  goto __pyx_L4_argument_unpacking_done;
  __pyx_L5_argtuple_error:;

 2968:         """
 2969:         binomial(n, p, size=None)
 2970: 
 2971:         Draw samples from a binomial distribution.
 2972: 
 2973:         Samples are drawn from a binomial distribution with specified
 2974:         parameters, n trials and p probability of success where
 2975:         n an integer >= 0 and p is in the interval [0,1]. (n may be
 2976:         input as a float, but it is truncated to an integer in use)
 2977: 
 2978:         Parameters
 2979:         ----------
 2980:         n : int or array_like of ints
 2981:             Parameter of the distribution, >= 0. Floats are also accepted,
 2982:             but they will be truncated to integers.
 2983:         p : float or array_like of floats
 2984:             Parameter of the distribution, >= 0 and <=1.
 2985:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2986:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2987:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2988:             a single value is returned if ``n`` and ``p`` are both scalars.
 2989:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(n, p).size`` samples are drawn.
 2990: 
 2991:         Returns
 2992:         -------
 2993:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2994:             Drawn samples from the parameterized binomial distribution, where
 2995:             each sample is equal to the number of successes over the n trials.
 2996: 
 2997:         See Also
 2998:         --------
 2999:         scipy.stats.binom : probability density function, distribution or
 3000:             cumulative density function, etc.
 3001: 
 3002:         Notes
 3003:         -----
 3004:         The probability density for the binomial distribution is
 3005: 
 3006:         .. math:: P(N) = \\binom{n}{N}p^N(1-p)^{n-N},
 3007: 
 3008:         where :math:`n` is the number of trials, :math:`p` is the probability
 3009:         of success, and :math:`N` is the number of successes.
 3010: 
 3011:         When estimating the standard error of a proportion in a population by
 3012:         using a random sample, the normal distribution works well unless the
 3013:         product p*n <=5, where p = population proportion estimate, and n =
 3014:         number of samples, in which case the binomial distribution is used
 3015:         instead. For example, a sample of 15 people shows 4 who are left
 3016:         handed, and 11 who are right handed. Then p = 4/15 = 27%. 0.27*15 = 4,
 3017:         so the binomial distribution should be used in this case.
 3018: 
 3019:         References
 3020:         ----------
 3021:         .. [1] Dalgaard, Peter, "Introductory Statistics with R",
 3022:                Springer-Verlag, 2002.
 3023:         .. [2] Glantz, Stanton A. "Primer of Biostatistics.", McGraw-Hill,
 3024:                Fifth Edition, 2002.
 3025:         .. [3] Lentner, Marvin, "Elementary Applied Statistics", Bogden
 3026:                and Quigley, 1972.
 3027:         .. [4] Weisstein, Eric W. "Binomial Distribution." From MathWorld--A
 3028:                Wolfram Web Resource.
 3029:                https://mathworld.wolfram.com/BinomialDistribution.html
 3030:         .. [5] Wikipedia, "Binomial distribution",
 3031:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binomial_distribution
 3032: 
 3033:         Examples
 3034:         --------
 3035:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 3036: 
 3037:         >>> n, p = 10, .5  # number of trials, probability of each trial
 3038:         >>> s = np.random.binomial(n, p, 1000)
 3039:         # result of flipping a coin 10 times, tested 1000 times.
 3040: 
 3041:         A real world example. A company drills 9 wild-cat oil exploration
 3042:         wells, each with an estimated probability of success of 0.1. All nine
 3043:         wells fail. What is the probability of that happening?
 3044: 
 3045:         Let's do 20,000 trials of the model, and count the number that
 3046:         generate zero positive results.
 3047: 
 3048:         >>> sum(np.random.binomial(9, 0.1, 20000) == 0)/20000.
 3049:         # answer = 0.38885, or 38%.
 3050: 
 3051:         """
 3052: 
 3053:         # Uses a custom implementation since self._binomial is required
+3054:         cdef double _dp = 0
  __pyx_v__dp = 0.0;

+3055:         cdef long _in = 0
  __pyx_v__in = 0;

+3056:         cdef bint is_scalar = True
  __pyx_v_is_scalar = 1;

 3057:         cdef np.npy_intp i, cnt
 3058:         cdef np.ndarray randoms
 3059:         cdef long *randoms_data
 3060:         cdef np.broadcast it

 3109: 
+3110:     def negative_binomial(self, n, p, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_87negative_binomial(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_86negative_binomial[] = "\n        negative_binomial(n, p, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a negative binomial distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a negative binomial distribution with specified\n        parameters, `n` successes and `p` probability of success where `n`\n        is > 0 and `p` is in the interval (0, 1].\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        n : float or array_like of floats\n            Parameter of the distribution, > 0.\n        p : float or array_like of floats\n            Parameter of the distribution. Must satisfy 0 < p <= 1.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``n`` and ``p`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(n, p).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized negative binomial distribution,\n            where each sample is equal to N, the number of failures that\n            occurred before a total of n successes was reached.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability mass function of the negative binomial distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(N;n,p) = \\frac{\\Gamma(N+n)}{N!\\Gamma(n)}p^{n}(1-p)^{N},\n\n        where :math:`n` is the number of successes, :math:`p` is the\n        probability of success, :math:`N+n` is the number of trials, and\n        :math:`\\Gamma` is the gamma function. When :math:`n` is an integer,\n        :math:`\\frac{\\Gamma(N+n)}{N!\\Gamma(n)} = \\binom{N+n-1}{N}`, which is\n        the more common form of this term in the the pmf. The negative\n        binomial distribution gives the probability of N failures given n\n        successes, with a success on the last trial.\n\n        If one throws a die repeatedly until the third time a \"1\" appears,\n        then the ""probability distribution of the number of non-\"1\"s that\n        appear before the third \"1\" is a negative binomial distribution.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Negative Binomial Distribution.\" From\n               MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.\n               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/NegativeBinomialDistribution.html\n        .. [2] Wikipedia, \"Negative binomial distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_binomial_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        A real world example. A company drills wild-cat oil\n        exploration wells, each with an estimated probability of\n        success of 0.1. What is the probability of having one success\n        for each successive well, that is what is the probability of a\n        single success after drilling 5 wells, after 6 wells, etc.?\n\n        >>> s = np.random.negative_binomial(1, 0.1, 100000)\n        >>> for i in range(1, 11): # doctest: +SKIP\n        ...    probability = sum(s<i) / 100000.\n        ...    print(i, \"wells drilled, probability of one success =\", probability)\n\n        ";

 3111:         """
 3112:         negative_binomial(n, p, size=None)
 3113: 
 3114:         Draw samples from a negative binomial distribution.
 3115: 
 3116:         Samples are drawn from a negative binomial distribution with specified
 3117:         parameters, `n` successes and `p` probability of success where `n`
 3118:         is > 0 and `p` is in the interval (0, 1].
 3119: 
 3120:         Parameters
 3121:         ----------
 3122:         n : float or array_like of floats
 3123:             Parameter of the distribution, > 0.
 3124:         p : float or array_like of floats
 3125:             Parameter of the distribution. Must satisfy 0 < p <= 1.
 3126:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3127:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3128:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 3129:             a single value is returned if ``n`` and ``p`` are both scalars.
 3130:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(n, p).size`` samples are drawn.
 3131: 
 3132:         Returns
 3133:         -------
 3134:         out : ndarray or scalar
 3135:             Drawn samples from the parameterized negative binomial distribution,
 3136:             where each sample is equal to N, the number of failures that
 3137:             occurred before a total of n successes was reached.
 3138: 
 3139:         Notes
 3140:         -----
 3141:         The probability mass function of the negative binomial distribution is
 3142: 
 3143:         .. math:: P(N;n,p) = \\frac{\\Gamma(N+n)}{N!\\Gamma(n)}p^{n}(1-p)^{N},
 3144: 
 3145:         where :math:`n` is the number of successes, :math:`p` is the
 3146:         probability of success, :math:`N+n` is the number of trials, and
 3147:         :math:`\\Gamma` is the gamma function. When :math:`n` is an integer,
 3148:         :math:`\\frac{\\Gamma(N+n)}{N!\\Gamma(n)} = \\binom{N+n-1}{N}`, which is
 3149:         the more common form of this term in the the pmf. The negative
 3150:         binomial distribution gives the probability of N failures given n
 3151:         successes, with a success on the last trial.
 3152: 
 3153:         If one throws a die repeatedly until the third time a "1" appears,
 3154:         then the probability distribution of the number of non-"1"s that
 3155:         appear before the third "1" is a negative binomial distribution.
 3156: 
 3157:         References
 3158:         ----------
 3159:         .. [1] Weisstein, Eric W. "Negative Binomial Distribution." From
 3160:                MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.
 3161:                https://mathworld.wolfram.com/NegativeBinomialDistribution.html
 3162:         .. [2] Wikipedia, "Negative binomial distribution",
 3163:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_binomial_distribution
 3164: 
 3165:         Examples
 3166:         --------
 3167:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 3168: 
 3169:         A real world example. A company drills wild-cat oil
 3170:         exploration wells, each with an estimated probability of
 3171:         success of 0.1. What is the probability of having one success
 3172:         for each successive well, that is what is the probability of a
 3173:         single success after drilling 5 wells, after 6 wells, etc.?
 3174: 
 3175:         >>> s = np.random.negative_binomial(1, 0.1, 100000)
 3176:         >>> for i in range(1, 11): # doctest: +SKIP
 3177:         ...    probability = sum(s<i) / 100000.
 3178:         ...    print(i, "wells drilled, probability of one success =", probability)
 3179: 
 3180:         """
+3181:         out = disc(&legacy_negative_binomial, &self._aug_state, size, self.lock, 2, 0,
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_disc((&legacy_negative_binomial), (&__pyx_v_self->_aug_state), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 2, 0, __pyx_v_n, __pyx_n_u_n, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_POSITIVE, __pyx_v_p, __pyx_n_u_p, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_BOUNDED_GT_0_1, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3181, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_v_out = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;

 3182:                    n, "n", CONS_POSITIVE,
 3183:                    p, "p", CONS_BOUNDED_GT_0_1,
 3184:                    0.0, "", CONS_NONE)
 3185:         # Match historical output type
+3186:         return int64_to_long(out)

  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6mtrand_int64_to_long(__pyx_v_out); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3186, __pyx_L1_error)

 3187: 
+3188:     def poisson(self, lam=1.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_89poisson(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_88poisson[] = "\n        poisson(lam=1.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Poisson distribution.\n\n        The Poisson distribution is the limit of the binomial distribution\n        for large N.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        lam : float or array_like of floats\n            Expectation of interval, must be >= 0. A sequence of expectation\n            intervals must be broadcastable over the requested size.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``lam`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(lam).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Poisson distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The Poisson distribution\n\n        .. math:: f(k; \\lambda)=\\frac{\\lambda^k e^{-\\lambda}}{k!}\n\n        For events with an expected separation :math:`\\lambda` the Poisson\n        distribution :math:`f(k; \\lambda)` describes the probability of\n        :math:`k` events occurring within the observed\n        interval :math:`\\lambda`.\n\n        Because the output is limited to the range of the C int64 type, a\n        ValueError is raised when `lam` is within 10 sigma of the maximum\n        representable value.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Poisson Distribution.\"\n               From MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.\n               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/PoissonDistribution.html\n        .. [2] Wikipedia, \"Poisson distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poisson_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> import numpy as np\n        >>> s = np.random.poisson(5, 10000)\n\n        Display histog""ram of the sample:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 14, density=True)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        Draw each 100 values for lambda 100 and 500:\n\n        >>> s = np.random.poisson(lam=(100., 500.), size=(100, 2))\n\n        ";

 3190:         poisson(lam=1.0, size=None)
 3191: 
 3192:         Draw samples from a Poisson distribution.
 3193: 
 3194:         The Poisson distribution is the limit of the binomial distribution
 3195:         for large N.
 3196: 
 3197:         Parameters
 3198:         ----------
 3199:         lam : float or array_like of floats
 3200:             Expectation of interval, must be >= 0. A sequence of expectation
 3201:             intervals must be broadcastable over the requested size.
 3202:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3203:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3204:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 3205:             a single value is returned if ``lam`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 3206:             ``np.array(lam).size`` samples are drawn.
 3207: 
 3208:         Returns
 3209:         -------
 3210:         out : ndarray or scalar
 3211:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Poisson distribution.
 3212: 
 3213:         Notes

 3215:         The Poisson distribution
 3216: 
 3217:         .. math:: f(k; \\lambda)=\\frac{\\lambda^k e^{-\\lambda}}{k!}
 3218: 
 3219:         For events with an expected separation :math:`\\lambda` the Poisson
 3220:         distribution :math:`f(k; \\lambda)` describes the probability of
 3221:         :math:`k` events occurring within the observed
 3222:         interval :math:`\\lambda`.
 3223:

 3225:         ValueError is raised when `lam` is within 10 sigma of the maximum
 3226:         representable value.

 3234:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poisson_distribution

 3247:         >>> plt.show()

+3261:     def zipf(self, a, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_91zipf(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_90zipf[] = "\n        zipf(a, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Zipf distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a Zipf distribution with specified parameter\n        `a` > 1.\n\n        The Zipf distribution (also known as the zeta distribution) is a\n        continuous probability distribution that satisfies Zipf's law: the\n        frequency of an item is inversely proportional to its rank in a\n        frequency table.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        a : float or array_like of floats\n            Distribution parameter. Must be greater than 1.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Zipf distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.zipf : probability density function, distribution, or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density for the Zipf distribution is\n\n        .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{x^{-a}}{\\zeta(a)},\n\n        where :math:`\\zeta` is the Riemann Zeta function.\n\n        It is named for the American linguist George Kingsley Zipf, who noted\n        that the frequency of any word in a sample of a language is inversely\n        proportional to its rank in the frequency table.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Zipf, G. K., \"Selected Studies of the Principle of Relative\n               Frequency in Language,\" Cambridge, MA: Harvard Univ. Press,\n               1932.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> a = 2. # parameter\n        >>> s = np.random.zipf(a, 1000"")\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> from scipy import special  # doctest: +SKIP\n\n        Truncate s values at 50 so plot is interesting:\n\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s[s<50], 50, density=True)\n        >>> x = np.arange(1., 50.)\n        >>> y = x**(-a) / special.zetac(a)  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.plot(x, y/max(y), linewidth=2, color='r')  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 3262:         """
 3263:         zipf(a, size=None)
 3264: 
 3265:         Draw samples from a Zipf distribution.
 3266: 
 3267:         Samples are drawn from a Zipf distribution with specified parameter
 3268:         `a` > 1.
 3269: 
 3270:         The Zipf distribution (also known as the zeta distribution) is a
 3271:         continuous probability distribution that satisfies Zipf's law: the
 3272:         frequency of an item is inversely proportional to its rank in a
 3273:         frequency table.
 3274: 
 3275:         Parameters
 3276:         ----------
 3277:         a : float or array_like of floats
 3278:             Distribution parameter. Must be greater than 1.
 3279:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3280:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3281:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 3282:             a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 3283:             ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.
 3284: 
 3285:         Returns
 3286:         -------
 3287:         out : ndarray or scalar
 3288:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Zipf distribution.
 3289: 
 3290:         See Also
 3291:         --------
 3292:         scipy.stats.zipf : probability density function, distribution, or
 3293:             cumulative density function, etc.
 3294: 
 3295:         Notes
 3296:         -----
 3297:         The probability density for the Zipf distribution is
 3298: 
 3299:         .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{x^{-a}}{\\zeta(a)},
 3300: 
 3301:         where :math:`\\zeta` is the Riemann Zeta function.
 3302: 
 3303:         It is named for the American linguist George Kingsley Zipf, who noted
 3304:         that the frequency of any word in a sample of a language is inversely
 3305:         proportional to its rank in the frequency table.
 3306: 
 3307:         References
 3308:         ----------
 3309:         .. [1] Zipf, G. K., "Selected Studies of the Principle of Relative
 3310:                Frequency in Language," Cambridge, MA: Harvard Univ. Press,
 3311:                1932.
 3312: 
 3313:         Examples
 3314:         --------
 3315:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 3316: 
 3317:         >>> a = 2. # parameter
 3318:         >>> s = np.random.zipf(a, 1000)
 3319: 
 3320:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 3321:         the probability density function:
 3322: 
 3323:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 3324:         >>> from scipy import special  # doctest: +SKIP
 3325: 
 3326:         Truncate s values at 50 so plot is interesting:
 3327: 
 3328:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s[s<50], 50, density=True)
 3329:         >>> x = np.arange(1., 50.)
 3330:         >>> y = x**(-a) / special.zetac(a)  # doctest: +SKIP
 3331:         >>> plt.plot(x, y/max(y), linewidth=2, color='r')  # doctest: +SKIP
 3332:         >>> plt.show()
 3333: 
 3334:         """
+3335:         out = disc(&legacy_random_zipf, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 1, 0,
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);

 3341: 
+3342:     def geometric(self, p, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_93geometric(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_92geometric[] = "\n        geometric(p, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from the geometric distribution.\n\n        Bernoulli trials are experiments with one of two outcomes:\n        success or failure (an example of such an experiment is flipping\n        a coin). The geometric distribution models the number of trials\n        that must be run in order to achieve success. It is therefore\n        supported on the positive integers, ``k = 1, 2, ...``.\n\n        The probability mass function of the geometric distribution is\n\n        .. math:: f(k) = (1 - p)^{k - 1} p\n\n        where `p` is the probability of success of an individual trial.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        p : float or array_like of floats\n            The probability of success of an individual trial.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``p`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(p).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized geometric distribution.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw ten thousand values from the geometric distribution,\n        with the probability of an individual success equal to 0.35:\n\n        >>> z = np.random.geometric(p=0.35, size=10000)\n\n        How many trials succeeded after a single run?\n\n        >>> (z == 1).sum() / 10000.\n        0.34889999999999999 #random\n\n        ";
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_93geometric(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds) {
  PyObject *__pyx_v_p = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_v_size = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_r = 0;

  {

    values[1] = ((PyObject *)Py_None);
    if (unlikely(__pyx_kwds)) {
      Py_ssize_t kw_args;

      switch (pos_args) {
        case  2: values[1] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 1);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;

        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  0: break;
        default: goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;
      }
      kw_args = PyDict_Size(__pyx_kwds);
      switch (pos_args) {
        case  0:

        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  1:

          PyObject* value = __Pyx_PyDict_GetItemStr(__pyx_kwds, __pyx_n_s_size);

 3343:         """
 3344:         geometric(p, size=None)
 3345: 
 3346:         Draw samples from the geometric distribution.
 3347: 
 3348:         Bernoulli trials are experiments with one of two outcomes:
 3349:         success or failure (an example of such an experiment is flipping
 3350:         a coin). The geometric distribution models the number of trials
 3351:         that must be run in order to achieve success. It is therefore
 3352:         supported on the positive integers, ``k = 1, 2, ...``.
 3353: 
 3354:         The probability mass function of the geometric distribution is
 3355: 
 3356:         .. math:: f(k) = (1 - p)^{k - 1} p
 3357: 
 3358:         where `p` is the probability of success of an individual trial.
 3359: 
 3360:         Parameters
 3361:         ----------
 3362:         p : float or array_like of floats
 3363:             The probability of success of an individual trial.
 3364:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3365:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3366:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 3367:             a single value is returned if ``p`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 3368:             ``np.array(p).size`` samples are drawn.
 3369: 
 3370:         Returns
 3371:         -------
 3372:         out : ndarray or scalar
 3373:             Drawn samples from the parameterized geometric distribution.
 3374: 
 3375:         Examples
 3376:         --------
 3377:         Draw ten thousand values from the geometric distribution,
 3378:         with the probability of an individual success equal to 0.35:
 3379: 
 3380:         >>> z = np.random.geometric(p=0.35, size=10000)
 3381: 
 3382:         How many trials succeeded after a single run?
 3383: 
 3384:         >>> (z == 1).sum() / 10000.
 3385:         0.34889999999999999 #random
 3386: 
 3387:         """
+3388:         out = disc(&legacy_random_geometric, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 1, 0,
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_disc((&legacy_random_geometric), (&__pyx_v_self->_bitgen), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 1, 0, __pyx_v_p, __pyx_n_u_p, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_BOUNDED_GT_0_1, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3388, __pyx_L1_error)

  __pyx_t_2 = 0;

 3389:                    p, "p", CONS_BOUNDED_GT_0_1,
 3390:                    0.0, "", CONS_NONE,
 3391:                    0.0, "", CONS_NONE)
 3392:         # Match historical output type

 3394: 
+3395:     def hypergeometric(self, ngood, nbad, nsample, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_95hypergeometric(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_94hypergeometric[] = "\n        hypergeometric(ngood, nbad, nsample, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Hypergeometric distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a hypergeometric distribution with specified\n        parameters, `ngood` (ways to make a good selection), `nbad` (ways to make\n        a bad selection), and `nsample` (number of items sampled, which is less\n        than or equal to the sum ``ngood + nbad``).\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        ngood : int or array_like of ints\n            Number of ways to make a good selection. Must be nonnegative.\n        nbad : int or array_like of ints\n            Number of ways to make a bad selection. Must be nonnegative.\n        nsample : int or array_like of ints\n            Number of items sampled. Must be at least 1 and at most\n            ``ngood + nbad``.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if `ngood`, `nbad`, and `nsample`\n            are all scalars. Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(ngood, nbad, nsample).size``\n            samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized hypergeometric distribution. Each\n            sample is the number of good items within a randomly selected subset of\n            size `nsample` taken from a set of `ngood` good items and `nbad` bad items.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.hypergeom : probability density function, distribution or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density for the Hypergeometric distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(x) = \\frac{\\binom{g}{x}\\binom{b}{n-x}}{\\binom{g+b}{n}},\n\n        where :math:`0 \\le x \\le n` and :math:`n-b \\le x \\le g`\n\n        for P(x) the p""robability of ``x`` good results in the drawn sample,\n        g = `ngood`, b = `nbad`, and n = `nsample`.\n\n        Consider an urn with black and white marbles in it, `ngood` of them\n        are black and `nbad` are white. If you draw `nsample` balls without\n        replacement, then the hypergeometric distribution describes the\n        distribution of black balls in the drawn sample.\n\n        Note that this distribution is very similar to the binomial\n        distribution, except that in this case, samples are drawn without\n        replacement, whereas in the Binomial case samples are drawn with\n        replacement (or the sample space is infinite). As the sample space\n        becomes large, this distribution approaches the binomial.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Lentner, Marvin, \"Elementary Applied Statistics\", Bogden\n               and Quigley, 1972.\n        .. [2] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Hypergeometric Distribution.\" From\n               MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.\n               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/HypergeometricDistribution.html\n        .. [3] Wikipedia, \"Hypergeometric distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypergeometric_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> ngood, nbad, nsamp = 100, 2, 10\n        # number of good, number of bad, and number of samples\n        >>> s = np.random.hypergeometric(ngood, nbad, nsamp, 1000)\n        >>> from matplotlib.pyplot import hist\n        >>> hist(s)\n        #   note that it is very unlikely to grab both bad items\n\n        Suppose you have an urn with 15 white and 15 black marbles.\n        If you pull 15 marbles at random, how likely is it that\n        12 or more of them are one color?\n\n        >>> s = np.random.hypergeometric(15, 15, 15, 100000)\n        >>> sum(s>=12)/100000. + sum(s<=3)/100000.\n        #   answer = 0.003 ... pretty unlikely!\n\n        ";

 3396:         """
 3397:         hypergeometric(ngood, nbad, nsample, size=None)
 3398: 
 3399:         Draw samples from a Hypergeometric distribution.
 3400: 
 3401:         Samples are drawn from a hypergeometric distribution with specified
 3402:         parameters, `ngood` (ways to make a good selection), `nbad` (ways to make
 3403:         a bad selection), and `nsample` (number of items sampled, which is less
 3404:         than or equal to the sum ``ngood + nbad``).
 3405: 
 3406:         Parameters
 3407:         ----------
 3408:         ngood : int or array_like of ints
 3409:             Number of ways to make a good selection. Must be nonnegative.
 3410:         nbad : int or array_like of ints
 3411:             Number of ways to make a bad selection. Must be nonnegative.
 3412:         nsample : int or array_like of ints
 3413:             Number of items sampled. Must be at least 1 and at most
 3414:             ``ngood + nbad``.
 3415:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3416:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3417:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 3418:             a single value is returned if `ngood`, `nbad`, and `nsample`
 3419:             are all scalars. Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(ngood, nbad, nsample).size``
 3420:             samples are drawn.
 3421: 
 3422:         Returns
 3423:         -------
 3424:         out : ndarray or scalar
 3425:             Drawn samples from the parameterized hypergeometric distribution. Each
 3426:             sample is the number of good items within a randomly selected subset of
 3427:             size `nsample` taken from a set of `ngood` good items and `nbad` bad items.
 3428: 
 3429:         See Also
 3430:         --------
 3431:         scipy.stats.hypergeom : probability density function, distribution or
 3432:             cumulative density function, etc.
 3433: 
 3434:         Notes
 3435:         -----
 3436:         The probability density for the Hypergeometric distribution is
 3437: 
 3438:         .. math:: P(x) = \\frac{\\binom{g}{x}\\binom{b}{n-x}}{\\binom{g+b}{n}},
 3439: 
 3440:         where :math:`0 \\le x \\le n` and :math:`n-b \\le x \\le g`
 3441: 
 3442:         for P(x) the probability of ``x`` good results in the drawn sample,
 3443:         g = `ngood`, b = `nbad`, and n = `nsample`.
 3444: 
 3445:         Consider an urn with black and white marbles in it, `ngood` of them
 3446:         are black and `nbad` are white. If you draw `nsample` balls without
 3447:         replacement, then the hypergeometric distribution describes the
 3448:         distribution of black balls in the drawn sample.
 3449: 
 3450:         Note that this distribution is very similar to the binomial
 3451:         distribution, except that in this case, samples are drawn without
 3452:         replacement, whereas in the Binomial case samples are drawn with
 3453:         replacement (or the sample space is infinite). As the sample space
 3454:         becomes large, this distribution approaches the binomial.
 3455: 
 3456:         References
 3457:         ----------
 3458:         .. [1] Lentner, Marvin, "Elementary Applied Statistics", Bogden
 3459:                and Quigley, 1972.
 3460:         .. [2] Weisstein, Eric W. "Hypergeometric Distribution." From
 3461:                MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.
 3462:                https://mathworld.wolfram.com/HypergeometricDistribution.html
 3463:         .. [3] Wikipedia, "Hypergeometric distribution",
 3464:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypergeometric_distribution
 3465: 
 3466:         Examples
 3467:         --------
 3468:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 3469: 
 3470:         >>> ngood, nbad, nsamp = 100, 2, 10
 3471:         # number of good, number of bad, and number of samples
 3472:         >>> s = np.random.hypergeometric(ngood, nbad, nsamp, 1000)
 3473:         >>> from matplotlib.pyplot import hist
 3474:         >>> hist(s)
 3475:         #   note that it is very unlikely to grab both bad items
 3476: 
 3477:         Suppose you have an urn with 15 white and 15 black marbles.
 3478:         If you pull 15 marbles at random, how likely is it that
 3479:         12 or more of them are one color?
 3480: 
 3481:         >>> s = np.random.hypergeometric(15, 15, 15, 100000)
 3482:         >>> sum(s>=12)/100000. + sum(s<=3)/100000.
 3483:         #   answer = 0.003 ... pretty unlikely!
 3484: 
 3485:         """
 3486:         cdef np.ndarray ongood, onbad, onsample
 3487:         cdef int64_t lngood, lnbad, lnsample
 3488: 
 3489:         # This cast to long is required to ensure that the values are inbounds
+3490:         ongood = <np.ndarray>np.PyArray_FROM_OTF(ngood, np.NPY_LONG, api.NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED)
  __pyx_t_1 = PyArray_FROM_OTF(__pyx_v_ngood, NPY_LONG, NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_1)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3490, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_1);
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_t_1;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_v_ongood = ((PyArrayObject *)__pyx_t_2);
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;

+3491:         onbad = <np.ndarray>np.PyArray_FROM_OTF(nbad, np.NPY_LONG, api.NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED)
  __pyx_t_2 = PyArray_FROM_OTF(__pyx_v_nbad, NPY_LONG, NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3491, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_t_2;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_2); __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  __pyx_v_onbad = ((PyArrayObject *)__pyx_t_1);
  __pyx_t_1 = 0;

+3492:         onsample = <np.ndarray>np.PyArray_FROM_OTF(nsample, np.NPY_LONG, api.NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED)
  __pyx_t_1 = PyArray_FROM_OTF(__pyx_v_nsample, NPY_LONG, NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_1)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3492, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_1);
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_t_1;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_v_onsample = ((PyArrayObject *)__pyx_t_2);
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;

 3493: 
+3494:         if np.PyArray_NDIM(ongood) == np.PyArray_NDIM(onbad) == np.PyArray_NDIM(onsample) == 0:

    }

  if (__pyx_t_6) {

  }

+3497:             lnbad = <int64_t>nbad
    __pyx_t_7 = __Pyx_PyInt_As_int64_t(__pyx_v_nbad); if (unlikely((__pyx_t_7 == ((int64_t)-1)) && PyErr_Occurred())) __PYX_ERR(0, 3497, __pyx_L1_error)

+3522:     def logseries(self, p, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_97logseries(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_96logseries[] = "\n        logseries(p, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a logarithmic series distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a log series distribution with specified\n        shape parameter, 0 < ``p`` < 1.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        p : float or array_like of floats\n            Shape parameter for the distribution. Must be in the range (0, 1).\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``p`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(p).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized logarithmic series distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.logser : probability density function, distribution or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density for the Log Series distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(k) = \\frac{-p^k}{k \\ln(1-p)},\n\n        where p = probability.\n\n        The log series distribution is frequently used to represent species\n        richness and occurrence, first proposed by Fisher, Corbet, and\n        Williams in 1943 [2]. It may also be used to model the numbers of\n        occupants seen in cars [3].\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Buzas, Martin A.; Culver, Stephen J.,  Understanding regional\n               species diversity through the log series distribution of\n               occurrences: BIODIVERSITY RESEARCH Diversity & Distributions,\n               Volume 5, Number 5, September 1999 , pp. 187-195(9).\n        .. [2] Fisher, R.A,, A.S. Corbet, and C.B. Williams. 1943. The\n               relation between the number of species and the number of\n               individuals in a random sampl""e of an animal population.\n               Journal of Animal Ecology, 12:42-58.\n        .. [3] D. J. Hand, F. Daly, D. Lunn, E. Ostrowski, A Handbook of Small\n               Data Sets, CRC Press, 1994.\n        .. [4] Wikipedia, \"Logarithmic distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logarithmic_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> a = .6\n        >>> s = np.random.logseries(a, 10000)\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s)\n\n        #   plot against distribution\n\n        >>> def logseries(k, p):\n        ...     return -p**k/(k*np.log(1-p))\n        >>> plt.plot(bins, logseries(bins, a)*count.max()/\n        ...          logseries(bins, a).max(), 'r')\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 3523:         """
 3524:         logseries(p, size=None)
 3525: 
 3526:         Draw samples from a logarithmic series distribution.
 3527: 
 3528:         Samples are drawn from a log series distribution with specified
 3529:         shape parameter, 0 < ``p`` < 1.
 3530: 
 3531:         Parameters
 3532:         ----------
 3533:         p : float or array_like of floats
 3534:             Shape parameter for the distribution. Must be in the range (0, 1).
 3535:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3536:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3537:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 3538:             a single value is returned if ``p`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 3539:             ``np.array(p).size`` samples are drawn.
 3540: 
 3541:         Returns
 3542:         -------
 3543:         out : ndarray or scalar
 3544:             Drawn samples from the parameterized logarithmic series distribution.
 3545: 
 3546:         See Also
 3547:         --------
 3548:         scipy.stats.logser : probability density function, distribution or
 3549:             cumulative density function, etc.
 3550: 
 3551:         Notes
 3552:         -----
 3553:         The probability density for the Log Series distribution is
 3554: 
 3555:         .. math:: P(k) = \\frac{-p^k}{k \\ln(1-p)},
 3556: 
 3557:         where p = probability.
 3558: 
 3559:         The log series distribution is frequently used to represent species
 3560:         richness and occurrence, first proposed by Fisher, Corbet, and
 3561:         Williams in 1943 [2]. It may also be used to model the numbers of
 3562:         occupants seen in cars [3].
 3563: 
 3564:         References
 3565:         ----------
 3566:         .. [1] Buzas, Martin A.; Culver, Stephen J.,  Understanding regional
 3567:                species diversity through the log series distribution of
 3568:                occurrences: BIODIVERSITY RESEARCH Diversity & Distributions,
 3569:                Volume 5, Number 5, September 1999 , pp. 187-195(9).
 3570:         .. [2] Fisher, R.A,, A.S. Corbet, and C.B. Williams. 1943. The
 3571:                relation between the number of species and the number of
 3572:                individuals in a random sample of an animal population.
 3573:                Journal of Animal Ecology, 12:42-58.
 3574:         .. [3] D. J. Hand, F. Daly, D. Lunn, E. Ostrowski, A Handbook of Small
 3575:                Data Sets, CRC Press, 1994.
 3576:         .. [4] Wikipedia, "Logarithmic distribution",
 3577:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logarithmic_distribution
 3578: 
 3579:         Examples
 3580:         --------
 3581:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 3582: 
 3583:         >>> a = .6
 3584:         >>> s = np.random.logseries(a, 10000)
 3585:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 3586:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s)
 3587: 
 3588:         #   plot against distribution
 3589: 
 3590:         >>> def logseries(k, p):
 3591:         ...     return -p**k/(k*np.log(1-p))
 3592:         >>> plt.plot(bins, logseries(bins, a)*count.max()/
 3593:         ...          logseries(bins, a).max(), 'r')
 3594:         >>> plt.show()
 3595: 
 3596:         """
+3597:         out = disc(&legacy_random_logseries, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 1, 0,
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/* … */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_disc((&legacy_random_logseries), (&__pyx_v_self->_bitgen), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 1, 0, __pyx_v_p, __pyx_n_u_p, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_BOUNDED_0_1, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__12, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3597, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_v_out = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;

 3598:                    p, "p", CONS_BOUNDED_0_1,
 3599:                    0.0, "", CONS_NONE,
 3600:                    0.0, "", CONS_NONE)
 3601:         # Match historical output type
+3602:         return int64_to_long(out)
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6mtrand_int64_to_long(__pyx_v_out); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3602, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 3603: 
 3604:     # Multivariate distributions:
+3605:     def multivariate_normal(self, mean, cov, size=None, check_valid="warn",
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_99multivariate_normal(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_98multivariate_normal[] = "\n        multivariate_normal(mean, cov, size=None, check_valid='warn', tol=1e-8)\n\n        Draw random samples from a multivariate normal distribution.\n\n        The multivariate normal, multinormal or Gaussian distribution is a\n        generalization of the one-dimensional normal distribution to higher\n        dimensions. Such a distribution is specified by its mean and\n        covariance matrix. These parameters are analogous to the mean\n        (average or \"center\") and variance (standard deviation, or \"width,\"\n        squared) of the one-dimensional normal distribution.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        mean : 1-D array_like, of length N\n            Mean of the N-dimensional distribution.\n        cov : 2-D array_like, of shape (N, N)\n            Covariance matrix of the distribution. It must be symmetric and\n            positive-semidefinite for proper sampling.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Given a shape of, for example, ``(m,n,k)``, ``m*n*k`` samples are\n            generated, and packed in an `m`-by-`n`-by-`k` arrangement. Because\n            each sample is `N`-dimensional, the output shape is ``(m,n,k,N)``.\n            If no shape is specified, a single (`N`-D) sample is returned.\n        check_valid : { 'warn', 'raise', 'ignore' }, optional\n            Behavior when the covariance matrix is not positive semidefinite.\n        tol : float, optional\n            Tolerance when checking the singular values in covariance matrix.\n            cov is cast to double before the check.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray\n            The drawn samples, of shape *size*, if that was provided. If not,\n            the shape is ``(N,)``.\n\n            In other words, each entry ``out[i,j,...,:]`` is an N-dimensional\n            value drawn from the distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The mean is a coordinate in N-dimensional space, which represents the\n      ""  location where samples are most likely to be generated. This is\n        analogous to the peak of the bell curve for the one-dimensional or\n        univariate normal distribution.\n\n        Covariance indicates the level to which two variables vary together.\n        From the multivariate normal distribution, we draw N-dimensional\n        samples, :math:`X = [x_1, x_2, ... x_N]`. The covariance matrix\n        element :math:`C_{ij}` is the covariance of :math:`x_i` and :math:`x_j`.\n        The element :math:`C_{ii}` is the variance of :math:`x_i` (i.e. its\n        \"spread\").\n\n        Instead of specifying the full covariance matrix, popular\n        approximations include:\n\n          - Spherical covariance (`cov` is a multiple of the identity matrix)\n          - Diagonal covariance (`cov` has non-negative elements, and only on\n            the diagonal)\n\n        This geometrical property can be seen in two dimensions by plotting\n        generated data-points:\n\n        >>> mean = [0, 0]\n        >>> cov = [[1, 0], [0, 100]]  # diagonal covariance\n\n        Diagonal covariance means that points are oriented along x or y-axis:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> x, y = np.random.multivariate_normal(mean, cov, 5000).T\n        >>> plt.plot(x, y, 'x')\n        >>> plt.axis('equal')\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        Note that the covariance matrix must be positive semidefinite (a.k.a.\n        nonnegative-definite). Otherwise, the behavior of this method is\n        undefined and backwards compatibility is not guaranteed.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Papoulis, A., \"Probability, Random Variables, and Stochastic\n               Processes,\" 3rd ed., New York: McGraw-Hill, 1991.\n        .. [2] Duda, R. O., Hart, P. E., and Stork, D. G., \"Pattern\n               Classification,\" 2nd ed., New York: Wiley, 2001.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        >>> mean = (1, 2)\n        >>> cov = [[1, 0""], [0, 1]]\n        >>> x = np.random.multivariate_normal(mean, cov, (3, 3))\n        >>> x.shape\n        (3, 3, 2)\n\n        The following is probably true, given that 0.6 is roughly twice the\n        standard deviation:\n\n        >>> list((x[0,0,:] - mean) < 0.6)\n        [True, True] # random\n\n        ";

 3606:                             tol=1e-8):
 3607:         """
 3608:         multivariate_normal(mean, cov, size=None, check_valid='warn', tol=1e-8)
 3609: 
 3610:         Draw random samples from a multivariate normal distribution.
 3611: 
 3612:         The multivariate normal, multinormal or Gaussian distribution is a
 3613:         generalization of the one-dimensional normal distribution to higher
 3614:         dimensions. Such a distribution is specified by its mean and
 3615:         covariance matrix. These parameters are analogous to the mean
 3616:         (average or "center") and variance (standard deviation, or "width,"
 3617:         squared) of the one-dimensional normal distribution.
 3618: 
 3619:         Parameters
 3620:         ----------
 3621:         mean : 1-D array_like, of length N
 3622:             Mean of the N-dimensional distribution.
 3623:         cov : 2-D array_like, of shape (N, N)
 3624:             Covariance matrix of the distribution. It must be symmetric and
 3625:             positive-semidefinite for proper sampling.
 3626:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3627:             Given a shape of, for example, ``(m,n,k)``, ``m*n*k`` samples are
 3628:             generated, and packed in an `m`-by-`n`-by-`k` arrangement. Because
 3629:             each sample is `N`-dimensional, the output shape is ``(m,n,k,N)``.
 3630:             If no shape is specified, a single (`N`-D) sample is returned.
 3631:         check_valid : { 'warn', 'raise', 'ignore' }, optional
 3632:             Behavior when the covariance matrix is not positive semidefinite.
 3633:         tol : float, optional
 3634:             Tolerance when checking the singular values in covariance matrix.
 3635:             cov is cast to double before the check.
 3636: 
 3637:         Returns
 3638:         -------
 3639:         out : ndarray
 3640:             The drawn samples, of shape *size*, if that was provided. If not,
 3641:             the shape is ``(N,)``.
 3642: 
 3643:             In other words, each entry ``out[i,j,...,:]`` is an N-dimensional
 3644:             value drawn from the distribution.
 3645: 
 3646:         Notes
 3647:         -----
 3648:         The mean is a coordinate in N-dimensional space, which represents the
 3649:         location where samples are most likely to be generated. This is
 3650:         analogous to the peak of the bell curve for the one-dimensional or
 3651:         univariate normal distribution.
 3652: 
 3653:         Covariance indicates the level to which two variables vary together.
 3654:         From the multivariate normal distribution, we draw N-dimensional
 3655:         samples, :math:`X = [x_1, x_2, ... x_N]`. The covariance matrix
 3656:         element :math:`C_{ij}` is the covariance of :math:`x_i` and :math:`x_j`.
 3657:         The element :math:`C_{ii}` is the variance of :math:`x_i` (i.e. its
 3658:         "spread").
 3659: 
 3660:         Instead of specifying the full covariance matrix, popular
 3661:         approximations include:
 3662: 
 3663:           - Spherical covariance (`cov` is a multiple of the identity matrix)
 3664:           - Diagonal covariance (`cov` has non-negative elements, and only on
 3665:             the diagonal)
 3666: 
 3667:         This geometrical property can be seen in two dimensions by plotting
 3668:         generated data-points:
 3669: 
 3670:         >>> mean = [0, 0]
 3671:         >>> cov = [[1, 0], [0, 100]]  # diagonal covariance
 3672: 
 3673:         Diagonal covariance means that points are oriented along x or y-axis:
 3674: 
 3675:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 3676:         >>> x, y = np.random.multivariate_normal(mean, cov, 5000).T
 3677:         >>> plt.plot(x, y, 'x')
 3678:         >>> plt.axis('equal')
 3679:         >>> plt.show()
 3680: 
 3681:         Note that the covariance matrix must be positive semidefinite (a.k.a.
 3682:         nonnegative-definite). Otherwise, the behavior of this method is
 3683:         undefined and backwards compatibility is not guaranteed.
 3684: 
 3685:         References
 3686:         ----------
 3687:         .. [1] Papoulis, A., "Probability, Random Variables, and Stochastic
 3688:                Processes," 3rd ed., New York: McGraw-Hill, 1991.
 3689:         .. [2] Duda, R. O., Hart, P. E., and Stork, D. G., "Pattern
 3690:                Classification," 2nd ed., New York: Wiley, 2001.
 3691: 
 3692:         Examples
 3693:         --------
 3694:         >>> mean = (1, 2)
 3695:         >>> cov = [[1, 0], [0, 1]]
 3696:         >>> x = np.random.multivariate_normal(mean, cov, (3, 3))
 3697:         >>> x.shape
 3698:         (3, 3, 2)
 3699: 
 3700:         The following is probably true, given that 0.6 is roughly twice the
 3701:         standard deviation:
 3702: 
 3703:         >>> list((x[0,0,:] - mean) < 0.6)
 3704:         [True, True] # random
 3705: 
 3706:         """
+3707:         from numpy.linalg import svd
  __pyx_t_1 = PyList_New(1); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_1)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3707, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_1);

  __pyx_v_svd = __pyx_t_1;

  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_2); __pyx_t_2 = 0;

 3708: 
 3709:         # Check preconditions on arguments
+3710:         mean = np.array(mean)
  __Pyx_GetModuleGlobalName(__pyx_t_1, __pyx_n_s_np); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_1)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3710, __pyx_L1_error)

  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_t_1 = NULL;
  if (CYTHON_UNPACK_METHODS && unlikely(PyMethod_Check(__pyx_t_3))) {
    __pyx_t_1 = PyMethod_GET_SELF(__pyx_t_3);
    if (likely(__pyx_t_1)) {

      __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
      __Pyx_INCREF(function);
      __Pyx_DECREF_SET(__pyx_t_3, function);
    }
  }
  __pyx_t_2 = (__pyx_t_1) ? __Pyx_PyObject_Call2Args(__pyx_t_3, __pyx_t_1, __pyx_v_mean) : __Pyx_PyObject_CallOneArg(__pyx_t_3, __pyx_v_mean);
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3710, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_3); __pyx_t_3 = 0;
  __Pyx_DECREF_SET(__pyx_v_mean, __pyx_t_2);
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;

+3711:         cov = np.array(cov)
  __Pyx_GetModuleGlobalName(__pyx_t_3, __pyx_n_s_np); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_3)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3711, __pyx_L1_error)

 3733: 
 3734:         # Transform matrix of standard normals into matrix where each row
 3735:         # contains multivariate normals with the desired covariance.
 3736:         # Compute A such that dot(transpose(A),A) == cov.
 3737:         # Then the matrix products of the rows of x and A has the desired
 3738:         # covariance. Note that sqrt(s)*v where (u,s,v) is the singular value
 3739:         # decomposition of cov is such an A.
 3740:         #
 3741:         # Also check that cov is positive-semidefinite. If so, the u.T and v
 3742:         # matrices should be equal up to roundoff error if cov is
 3743:         # symmetric and the singular value of the corresponding row is
 3744:         # not zero. We continue to use the SVD rather than Cholesky in
 3745:         # order to preserve current outputs. Note that symmetry has not
 3746:         # been checked.
 3747: 
 3748:         # GH10839, ensure double to make tol meaningful
+3749:         cov = cov.astype(np.double)
  __pyx_t_3 = __Pyx_PyObject_GetAttrStr(__pyx_v_cov, __pyx_n_s_astype); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_3)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3749, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_3);
  __Pyx_GetModuleGlobalName(__pyx_t_11, __pyx_n_s_np); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_11)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3749, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_11);
  __pyx_t_9 = __Pyx_PyObject_GetAttrStr(__pyx_t_11, __pyx_n_s_double); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_9)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3749, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_9);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_11); __pyx_t_11 = 0;
  __pyx_t_11 = NULL;
  if (CYTHON_UNPACK_METHODS && likely(PyMethod_Check(__pyx_t_3))) {
    __pyx_t_11 = PyMethod_GET_SELF(__pyx_t_3);
    if (likely(__pyx_t_11)) {
      PyObject* function = PyMethod_GET_FUNCTION(__pyx_t_3);
      __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_11);
      __Pyx_INCREF(function);
      __Pyx_DECREF_SET(__pyx_t_3, function);
    }
  }
  __pyx_t_2 = (__pyx_t_11) ? __Pyx_PyObject_Call2Args(__pyx_t_3, __pyx_t_11, __pyx_t_9) : __Pyx_PyObject_CallOneArg(__pyx_t_3, __pyx_t_9);
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_t_11); __pyx_t_11 = 0;
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_9); __pyx_t_9 = 0;
  if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3749, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_3); __pyx_t_3 = 0;
  __Pyx_DECREF_SET(__pyx_v_cov, __pyx_t_2);
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;

+3750:         (u, s, v) = svd(cov)
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_v_svd);
  __pyx_t_3 = __pyx_v_svd; __pyx_t_9 = NULL;
  if (CYTHON_UNPACK_METHODS && unlikely(PyMethod_Check(__pyx_t_3))) {
    __pyx_t_9 = PyMethod_GET_SELF(__pyx_t_3);
    if (likely(__pyx_t_9)) {
      PyObject* function = PyMethod_GET_FUNCTION(__pyx_t_3);
      __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_9);
      __Pyx_INCREF(function);
      __Pyx_DECREF_SET(__pyx_t_3, function);

+3768:         x.shape = tuple(final_shape)
  __pyx_t_13 = PyList_AsTuple(__pyx_v_final_shape); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_13)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3768, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_13);
  if (__Pyx_PyObject_SetAttrStr(__pyx_v_x, __pyx_n_s_shape, __pyx_t_13) < 0) __PYX_ERR(0, 3768, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_13); __pyx_t_13 = 0;

+3769:         return x
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_v_x);
  __pyx_r = __pyx_v_x;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 3770: 
+3771:     def multinomial(self, np.npy_intp n, object pvals, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_101multinomial(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_100multinomial[] = "\n        multinomial(n, pvals, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a multinomial distribution.\n\n        The multinomial distribution is a multivariate generalization of the\n        binomial distribution. Take an experiment with one of ``p``\n        possible outcomes. An example of such an experiment is throwing a dice,\n        where the outcome can be 1 through 6. Each sample drawn from the\n        distribution represents `n` such experiments. Its values,\n        ``X_i = [X_0, X_1, ..., X_p]``, represent the number of times the\n        outcome was ``i``.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        n : int\n            Number of experiments.\n        pvals : sequence of floats, length p\n            Probabilities of each of the ``p`` different outcomes. These\n            must sum to 1 (however, the last element is always assumed to\n            account for the remaining probability, as long as\n            ``sum(pvals[:-1]) <= 1)``.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. Default is None, in which case a\n            single value is returned.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray\n            The drawn samples, of shape *size*, if that was provided. If not,\n            the shape is ``(N,)``.\n\n            In other words, each entry ``out[i,j,...,:]`` is an N-dimensional\n            value drawn from the distribution.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Throw a dice 20 times:\n\n        >>> np.random.multinomial(20, [1/6.]*6, size=1)\n        array([[4, 1, 7, 5, 2, 1]]) # random\n\n        It landed 4 times on 1, once on 2, etc.\n\n        Now, throw the dice 20 times, and 20 times again:\n\n        >>> np.random.multinomial(20, [1/6.]*6, size=2)\n        array([[3, 4, 3, 3, 4, 3], # random\n               [2, 4, 3, 4, 0, 7]])\n\n        For the first run, we threw 3 times 1, 4 times 2, ""etc. For the second,\n        we threw 2 times 1, 4 times 2, etc.\n\n        A loaded die is more likely to land on number 6:\n\n        >>> np.random.multinomial(100, [1/7.]*5 + [2/7.])\n        array([11, 16, 14, 17, 16, 26]) # random\n\n        The probability inputs should be normalized. As an implementation\n        detail, the value of the last entry is ignored and assumed to take\n        up any leftover probability mass, but this should not be relied on.\n        A biased coin which has twice as much weight on one side as on the\n        other should be sampled like so:\n\n        >>> np.random.multinomial(100, [1.0 / 3, 2.0 / 3])  # RIGHT\n        array([38, 62]) # random\n\n        not like:\n\n        >>> np.random.multinomial(100, [1.0, 2.0])  # WRONG\n        Traceback (most recent call last):\n        ValueError: pvals < 0, pvals > 1 or pvals contains NaNs\n\n        ";

 3772:         """
 3773:         multinomial(n, pvals, size=None)
 3774: 
 3775:         Draw samples from a multinomial distribution.
 3776: 
 3777:         The multinomial distribution is a multivariate generalization of the
 3778:         binomial distribution. Take an experiment with one of ``p``
 3779:         possible outcomes. An example of such an experiment is throwing a dice,
 3780:         where the outcome can be 1 through 6. Each sample drawn from the
 3781:         distribution represents `n` such experiments. Its values,
 3782:         ``X_i = [X_0, X_1, ..., X_p]``, represent the number of times the
 3783:         outcome was ``i``.
 3784: 
 3785:         Parameters
 3786:         ----------
 3787:         n : int
 3788:             Number of experiments.
 3789:         pvals : sequence of floats, length p
 3790:             Probabilities of each of the ``p`` different outcomes. These
 3791:             must sum to 1 (however, the last element is always assumed to
 3792:             account for the remaining probability, as long as
 3793:             ``sum(pvals[:-1]) <= 1)``.
 3794:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3795:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3796:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. Default is None, in which case a
 3797:             single value is returned.
 3798: 
 3799:         Returns
 3800:         -------
 3801:         out : ndarray
 3802:             The drawn samples, of shape *size*, if that was provided. If not,
 3803:             the shape is ``(N,)``.
 3804: 
 3805:             In other words, each entry ``out[i,j,...,:]`` is an N-dimensional
 3806:             value drawn from the distribution.
 3807: 
 3808:         Examples
 3809:         --------
 3810:         Throw a dice 20 times:
 3811: 
 3812:         >>> np.random.multinomial(20, [1/6.]*6, size=1)
 3813:         array([[4, 1, 7, 5, 2, 1]]) # random
 3814: 
 3815:         It landed 4 times on 1, once on 2, etc.
 3816: 
 3817:         Now, throw the dice 20 times, and 20 times again:
 3818: 
 3819:         >>> np.random.multinomial(20, [1/6.]*6, size=2)
 3820:         array([[3, 4, 3, 3, 4, 3], # random
 3821:                [2, 4, 3, 4, 0, 7]])
 3822: 
 3823:         For the first run, we threw 3 times 1, 4 times 2, etc. For the second,
 3824:         we threw 2 times 1, 4 times 2, etc.
 3825: 
 3826:         A loaded die is more likely to land on number 6:
 3827: 
 3828:         >>> np.random.multinomial(100, [1/7.]*5 + [2/7.])
 3829:         array([11, 16, 14, 17, 16, 26]) # random
 3830: 
 3831:         The probability inputs should be normalized. As an implementation
 3832:         detail, the value of the last entry is ignored and assumed to take
 3833:         up any leftover probability mass, but this should not be relied on.
 3834:         A biased coin which has twice as much weight on one side as on the
 3835:         other should be sampled like so:
 3836: 
 3837:         >>> np.random.multinomial(100, [1.0 / 3, 2.0 / 3])  # RIGHT
 3838:         array([38, 62]) # random
 3839: 
 3840:         not like:
 3841: 
 3842:         >>> np.random.multinomial(100, [1.0, 2.0])  # WRONG
 3843:         Traceback (most recent call last):
 3844:         ValueError: pvals < 0, pvals > 1 or pvals contains NaNs
 3845: 
 3846:         """
 3847:         cdef np.npy_intp d, i, sz, offset
 3848:         cdef np.ndarray parr, mnarr
 3849:         cdef double *pix
 3850:         cdef long *mnix
 3851:         cdef long ni
 3852:

 3884: 
+3885:     def dirichlet(self, object alpha, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_103dirichlet(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_102dirichlet[] = "\n        dirichlet(alpha, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from the Dirichlet distribution.\n\n        Draw `size` samples of dimension k from a Dirichlet distribution. A\n        Dirichlet-distributed random variable can be seen as a multivariate\n        generalization of a Beta distribution. The Dirichlet distribution\n        is a conjugate prior of a multinomial distribution in Bayesian\n        inference.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        alpha : sequence of floats, length k\n            Parameter of the distribution (length ``k`` for sample of\n            length ``k``).\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape.  If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. Default is None, in which case a\n            vector of length ``k`` is returned.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        samples : ndarray,\n            The drawn samples, of shape ``(size, k)``.\n\n        Raises\n        -------\n        ValueError\n            If any value in ``alpha`` is less than or equal to zero.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The Dirichlet distribution is a distribution over vectors\n        :math:`x` that fulfil the conditions :math:`x_i>0` and\n        :math:`\\sum_{i=1}^k x_i = 1`.\n\n        The probability density function :math:`p` of a\n        Dirichlet-distributed random vector :math:`X` is\n        proportional to\n\n        .. math:: p(x) \\propto \\prod_{i=1}^{k}{x^{\\alpha_i-1}_i},\n\n        where :math:`\\alpha` is a vector containing the positive\n        concentration parameters.\n\n        The method uses the following property for computation: let :math:`Y`\n        be a random vector which has components that follow a standard gamma\n        distribution, then :math:`X = \\frac{1}{\\sum_{i=1}^k{Y_i}} Y`\n        is Dirichlet-distributed\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] David McKay, \"Information Theory, Inference and Learning""\n               Algorithms,\" chapter 23,\n               http://www.inference.org.uk/mackay/itila/\n        .. [2] Wikipedia, \"Dirichlet distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dirichlet_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Taking an example cited in Wikipedia, this distribution can be used if\n        one wanted to cut strings (each of initial length 1.0) into K pieces\n        with different lengths, where each piece had, on average, a designated\n        average length, but allowing some variation in the relative sizes of\n        the pieces.\n\n        >>> s = np.random.dirichlet((10, 5, 3), 20).transpose()\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> plt.barh(range(20), s[0])\n        >>> plt.barh(range(20), s[1], left=s[0], color='g')\n        >>> plt.barh(range(20), s[2], left=s[0]+s[1], color='r')\n        >>> plt.title(\"Lengths of Strings\")\n\n        ";
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_103dirichlet(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds) {
