 3886:         """
 3887:         dirichlet(alpha, size=None)
 3888: 
 3889:         Draw samples from the Dirichlet distribution.
 3890: 
 3891:         Draw `size` samples of dimension k from a Dirichlet distribution. A
 3892:         Dirichlet-distributed random variable can be seen as a multivariate
 3893:         generalization of a Beta distribution. The Dirichlet distribution
 3894:         is a conjugate prior of a multinomial distribution in Bayesian
 3895:         inference.
 3896: 
 3897:         Parameters
 3898:         ----------
 3899:         alpha : sequence of floats, length k
 3900:             Parameter of the distribution (length ``k`` for sample of
 3901:             length ``k``).
 3902:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3903:             Output shape.  If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n)``, then
 3904:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. Default is None, in which case a
 3905:             vector of length ``k`` is returned.
 3906: 
 3907:         Returns
 3908:         -------
 3909:         samples : ndarray,
 3910:             The drawn samples, of shape ``(size, k)``.
 3911: 
 3912:         Raises
 3913:         -------
 3914:         ValueError
 3915:             If any value in ``alpha`` is less than or equal to zero.
 3916: 
 3917:         Notes
 3918:         -----
 3919:         The Dirichlet distribution is a distribution over vectors
 3920:         :math:`x` that fulfil the conditions :math:`x_i>0` and
 3921:         :math:`\\sum_{i=1}^k x_i = 1`.
 3922: 
 3923:         The probability density function :math:`p` of a
 3924:         Dirichlet-distributed random vector :math:`X` is
 3925:         proportional to
 3926: 
 3927:         .. math:: p(x) \\propto \\prod_{i=1}^{k}{x^{\\alpha_i-1}_i},
 3928: 
 3929:         where :math:`\\alpha` is a vector containing the positive
 3930:         concentration parameters.
 3931: 
 3932:         The method uses the following property for computation: let :math:`Y`
 3933:         be a random vector which has components that follow a standard gamma
 3934:         distribution, then :math:`X = \\frac{1}{\\sum_{i=1}^k{Y_i}} Y`
 3935:         is Dirichlet-distributed
 3936: 
 3937:         References
 3938:         ----------
 3939:         .. [1] David McKay, "Information Theory, Inference and Learning
 3940:                Algorithms," chapter 23,
 3941:                http://www.inference.org.uk/mackay/itila/
 3942:         .. [2] Wikipedia, "Dirichlet distribution",
 3943:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dirichlet_distribution
 3944: 
 3945:         Examples
 3946:         --------
 3947:         Taking an example cited in Wikipedia, this distribution can be used if
 3948:         one wanted to cut strings (each of initial length 1.0) into K pieces
 3949:         with different lengths, where each piece had, on average, a designated
 3950:         average length, but allowing some variation in the relative sizes of
 3951:         the pieces.
 3952: 
 3953:         >>> s = np.random.dirichlet((10, 5, 3), 20).transpose()
 3954: 
 3955:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 3956:         >>> plt.barh(range(20), s[0])
 3957:         >>> plt.barh(range(20), s[1], left=s[0], color='g')
 3958:         >>> plt.barh(range(20), s[2], left=s[0]+s[1], color='r')
 3959:         >>> plt.title("Lengths of Strings")
 3960: 
 3961:         """
 3962: 
 3963:         # =================
 3964:         # Pure python algo
 3965:         # =================
 3966:         # alpha   = N.atleast_1d(alpha)
 3967:         # k       = alpha.size
 3968: 
 3969:         # if n == 1:
 3970:         #     val = N.zeros(k)
 3971:         #     for i in range(k):
 3972:         #         val[i]   = sgamma(alpha[i], n)
 3973:         #     val /= N.sum(val)
 3974:         # else:
 3975:         #     val = N.zeros((k, n))
 3976:         #     for i in range(k):
 3977:         #         val[i]   = sgamma(alpha[i], n)
 3978:         #     val /= N.sum(val, axis = 0)
 3979:         #     val = val.T
 3980:         # return val
 3981: 
 3982:         cdef np.npy_intp k, totsize, i, j
 3983:         cdef np.ndarray alpha_arr, val_arr
 3984:         cdef double *alpha_data
 3985:         cdef double *val_data
 3986:         cdef double  acc, invacc
 3987:

 4022:     # Shuffling and permutations:
+4023:     def shuffle(self, object x):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_105shuffle(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_v_x); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_104shuffle[] = "\n        shuffle(x)\n\n        Modify a sequence in-place by shuffling its contents.\n\n        This function only shuffles the array along the first axis of a\n        multi-dimensional array. The order of sub-arrays is changed but\n        their contents remains the same.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        x : array_like\n            The array or list to be shuffled.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        None\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        >>> arr = np.arange(10)\n        >>> np.random.shuffle(arr)\n        >>> arr\n        [1 7 5 2 9 4 3 6 0 8] # random\n\n        Multi-dimensional arrays are only shuffled along the first axis:\n\n        >>> arr = np.arange(9).reshape((3, 3))\n        >>> np.random.shuffle(arr)\n        >>> arr\n        array([[3, 4, 5], # random\n               [6, 7, 8],\n               [0, 1, 2]])\n\n        ";

 4024:         """
 4025:         shuffle(x)
 4026: 
 4027:         Modify a sequence in-place by shuffling its contents.
 4028: 
 4029:         This function only shuffles the array along the first axis of a
 4030:         multi-dimensional array. The order of sub-arrays is changed but
 4031:         their contents remains the same.
 4032: 
 4033:         Parameters
 4034:         ----------
 4035:         x : array_like
 4036:             The array or list to be shuffled.
 4037: 
 4038:         Returns
 4039:         -------
 4040:         None
 4041: 
 4042:         Examples
 4043:         --------
 4044:         >>> arr = np.arange(10)
 4045:         >>> np.random.shuffle(arr)
 4046:         >>> arr
 4047:         [1 7 5 2 9 4 3 6 0 8] # random
 4048: 
 4049:         Multi-dimensional arrays are only shuffled along the first axis:
 4050: 
 4051:         >>> arr = np.arange(9).reshape((3, 3))
 4052:         >>> np.random.shuffle(arr)
 4053:         >>> arr
 4054:         array([[3, 4, 5], # random
 4055:                [6, 7, 8],
 4056:                [0, 1, 2]])
 4057: 
 4058:         """
 4059:         cdef:

 4078:                 # We trick gcc into providing a specialized implementation for
 4079:                 # the most common case, yielding a ~33% performance improvement.
 4080:                 # Note that apparently, only one branch can ever be specialized.

+4102:     cdef inline _shuffle_raw(self, np.npy_intp n, np.npy_intp itemsize,
static CYTHON_INLINE PyObject *__pyx_f_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState__shuffle_raw(struct __pyx_obj_9randomgen_6mtrand_RandomState *__pyx_v_self, npy_intp __pyx_v_n, npy_intp __pyx_v_itemsize, npy_intp __pyx_v_stride, char *__pyx_v_data, char *__pyx_v_buf) {
  npy_intp __pyx_v_i;
  npy_intp __pyx_v_j;
  PyObject *__pyx_r = NULL;
  __Pyx_RefNannyDeclarations

/* Python wrapper */

static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_6mtrand_11RandomState_106permutation[] = "\n        permutation(x)\n\n        Randomly permute a sequence, or return a permuted range.\n\n        If `x` is a multi-dimensional array, it is only shuffled along its\n        first index.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        x : int or array_like\n            If `x` is an integer, randomly permute ``np.arange(x)``.\n            If `x` is an array, make a copy and shuffle the elements\n            randomly.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray\n            Permuted sequence or array range.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        >>> np.random.permutation(10)\n        array([1, 7, 4, 3, 0, 9, 2, 5, 8, 6]) # random\n\n        >>> np.random.permutation([1, 4, 9, 12, 15])\n        array([15,  1,  9,  4, 12]) # random\n\n        >>> arr = np.arange(9).reshape((3, 3))\n        >>> np.random.permutation(arr)\n        array([[6, 7, 8], # random\n               [0, 1, 2],\n               [3, 4, 5]])\n\n        ";

 4112:         """
 4113:         permutation(x)
 4114: 
 4115:         Randomly permute a sequence, or return a permuted range.
 4116: 
 4117:         If `x` is a multi-dimensional array, it is only shuffled along its
 4118:         first index.
 4119: 
 4120:         Parameters
 4121:         ----------
 4122:         x : int or array_like
 4123:             If `x` is an integer, randomly permute ``np.arange(x)``.
 4124:             If `x` is an array, make a copy and shuffle the elements
 4125:             randomly.
 4126: 
 4127:         Returns
 4128:         -------
 4129:         out : ndarray
 4130:             Permuted sequence or array range.
 4131: 
 4132:         Examples
 4133:         --------
 4134:         >>> np.random.permutation(10)
 4135:         array([1, 7, 4, 3, 0, 9, 2, 5, 8, 6]) # random
 4136: 
 4137:         >>> np.random.permutation([1, 4, 9, 12, 15])
 4138:         array([15,  1,  9,  4, 12]) # random
 4139: 
 4140:         >>> arr = np.arange(9).reshape((3, 3))
 4141:         >>> np.random.permutation(arr)
 4142:         array([[6, 7, 8], # random
